7.subject: News Alert: French doctor accused of sexually abusing hundreds of children is sentenced to 20 years

Or, open the following link to view this email in a browser: https://e.emailalerts.cnn.com/click? ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We respect your privacy, if this e-mail has been sent to you by error or you no longer wish to receive email, open the following link in a browser to unsubscribe: https://e.emailalerts.cnn.com/click?
A French court on Wednesday found a retired surgeon guilty of the rape and sexual assault of patients, some of them while under anesthetic, in a trial that has shaken France.

 

News Alert: French doctor accused of sexually abusing hundreds of children is sentenced to 20 years

A French court on Wednesday found a retired surgeon guilty of the rape and sexual assault of patients, some of them while under anesthetic, in a trial that has shaken France.

Joel Le Scouarnec had told the court he committed “despicable acts” over a 25-year period while he worked as doctor in western France, in a trial that has raised questions for the publicly run healthcare system.

Le Scouarnec, 74, was sentenced to 20 years in jail.

Read More

12.subject: America Turns Its Back on the World

13.subject: The sound of silence
13.body:
Presented by The National Association of REALTORS®: The unofficial guide to official Washington.  May 28, 2025 View in browser  
By Jack Blanchard with Dasha Burns

Presented by 

With help from Eli Okun and Bethany Irvine


Listen to today's Playbook Podcast

Good Wednesday morning. This is Jack Blanchard.

MARK YOUR CALENDARS: The Conversation with Dasha Burns arrives on Sunday, June 1 — and we’re dropping a first look. Each week on her new podcast, Dasha will sit down with one of the most compelling — and sometimes unexpected — power players in Washington. This isn’t just a podcast. It’s a new kind of political interview show for a moment when politics feels more personal, more chaotic and more consequential than ever. Catch the video and audio trailer out this morning to see what Dasha’s digging into this season. And subscribe to the podcast, wherever you listen or watch.

And yes … You can still catch Dasha Monday through Thursday mornings as well, on the Playbook Podcast with yours truly. You don’t get rid of us that easy.

In today’s Playbook …

— The president takes a media hiatus ... but fear not! We’ll always have his socials.

— Vance and the Trump boys go full crypto-bro in Vegas.

— Why gubernatorials are currently the races to watch.

 DRIVING THE DAY


A quick trawl through the archives suggests President Donald Trump has done media on 111 of his 138 days back in office. | Julia Demaree Nikhinson/AP Photo

THE SOUND OF SILENCE: By lunchtime today it will have been 48 hours since Donald Trump stepped in front of a TV camera for a speech or Q&A — the first time that’s happened (outside of the weekends) since he returned to the White House on Jan. 20. Whatever your politics, that’s a remarkable record of public availability, especially when compared to his famously sheltered predecessor. And look how that turned out.

By the numbers: A quick trawl through the archives suggests Trump 2.0 has done media on 111 of his 138 days back in office — an 80 percent hit rate that includes weekends and must put him on course to being just about the most-accessible president in modern history. And aside from the lamentable attempt to ban AP, he’s basically taken questions from all-comers. It’s impressive stuff.

And it matters: In case anyone still needs this hammering home for them, the Joe Biden experience shows just how important it is that leaders are held up to regular scrutiny. Trump’s answers may sometimes be rambling, erratic — or even downright unpleasant — but every American voter can see where he’s at.

So why the sudden silence? Trump has no scheduled media appearances today, for the second-consecutive day — though it’s still possible a 2 p.m. closed-doors “executive order” session turns into one of his freeform Q&As. Either way, no one thinks he’s shirking. Aides tell my Playbook colleague Dasha Burns Trump spent yesterday holding calls and meetings in the Oval Office, and on this morning’s Playbook Podcast she predicts we’re likely just witnessing the calm before the next storm.

Storm watch: We’re still expecting a big announcement on Iran as soon as this week — the NYT reports this would be a “declaration of some common principles” rather than a fully fledged nuclear deal — and Russia sanctions may or may not be in the offing, with Trump lashing out at President Vladimir Putin again yesterday … Everybody is praying for some sort of breakthrough on Gaza, especially after the aid chaos we saw yesterday … And the whole ‘war on Harvard’ thing doesn’t appear to be losing any steam. Trump has posted about the Ivy League university multiple times on Truth Social the past few days.

Speaking of Truth Social: Close observers may have noticed that Trump’s innate — how can we put this kindly? — desire to be heard has rather spilled out on social media during his brief MSM hiatus. Aside from the memes, reposts and videos that always pepper his feed, Trump posted nine genuine messages yesterday, another nine on Monday and eight on Sunday ... Which averages out about once every couple of hours, after you’ve factored in sleep. (If indeed, the president does sleep.)

What’s on Trump’s mind: Fannie Mae and Fannie Mac … Biden and the autopen … Jobs in Alaska … Fishing in Maine … Canada becoming the “51st state” … Border Patrol … Putin … Tariffs on Europe … California athletics … And that was just yesterday. Silence is not quite the right word for where we’re at.

  BEGIN-REGION Playbook1   
A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:

The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act is positive for homeownership and the middle class, with strong bipartisan voter backing. Key provisions—like lower tax rates, SALT relief, and incentives for small businesses and community investment—make housing more affordable and strengthen communities and the American Dream. While this bill brings real benefits, more bipartisan action is needed to reduce housing costs. Learn more.
    END-REGION 
Nevertheless: It does feel like at least some of the relentless, minute-by-minute drama of Trump’s first months back in power has started to fade. Elon Musk’s all-consuming DOGE project feels much less significant since its principle character slinked back to the world of tech. Trump’s market-wobbling tariff wars have become a series of snarled-up trade talks. The Ukraine war looks intractable. Mass deportations have been hampered by limited resources and the courts. Those of us covering the White House can actually take a quick breath.

And speaking of Musk … Filling the Trump-shaped void this morning is none other than Musk himself, now reverting back to his former tech-geek persona after tanking Tesla’s image (and value) with his brief sojourn into politics. Flaunting an “Occupy Mars” T-shirt rather than a MAGA hat in an interview with CBS, Musk seeks to put some clear blue water between himself and the GOP by criticising the budget passed by the House.

Regrets, I’ve had a few: Musk also did a sit-down with WaPo, in which he laments the reputational damage caused by his chainsaw-wielding work for the White House. “DOGE is just becoming the whipping boy for everything,” Musk complained. “Something bad would happen anywhere, and we would get blamed for it even if we had nothing to do with it.” Sympathy levels within the federal government will be pretty low.

  BEGIN-REGION Playbook2   
A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:



The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act supports the middle class with broad voter support for provisions that boost housing affordability, community investment, and small businesses. Learn more.
    END-REGION 
COINING IT IN

TRUMP’S CRYPTO PLAY: Unusually, the biggest political event in the diary this morning is happening in Las Vegas, where the astonishing overlap between Trump’s political and personal interests will again be on display.

First, the political … At 12 noon Eastern, VP JD Vance will deliver the keynote address at the Bitcoin 2025 Conference in Vegas, setting out the administration’s full-speed-ahead approach to the U.S. crypto industry. It’s the same conference Trump headlined in person last year, promising America would become a “bitcoin superpower” under his leadership. He’s certainly been true to his word, per CNBC.

Then, the personal … At 4:30 p.m., Trump’s sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr. will speak at the very same conference in Vegas. It’s presumably an industry they feel invested in, given they back a major Bitcoin venture themselves, per Reuters. And it comes just a day after a separate family-linked business, the Trump Media & Technology Group, announced its intention to raise $2.5 billion to invest in bitcoin, as WSJ’s Alexander Osipovich and Jennifer Calfas report. And that in turn came after Trump offered out exclusive VIP dinner invites to the 220 top buyers of his personal $Trump memecoin, as an incentive to buy more stock. It’s all head-spinning stuff for a president of the United States.

More news from Vegas: Coinbase chief policy officer Faryar Shirzad announced yesterday that the cryptocurrency exchange will be a “major sponsor” of America250, the Trump-affiliated committee organizing celebrations of the 250th birthday for the U.S. And this isn’t Coinbase's first donation to a Trump committee, notes The Verge’s Tina Nguyen. It “previously donated $1 million to Trump’s inauguration committee,” she writes on X. “The SEC dropped a lawsuit against Coinbase a month later.”

And a P.S. from Vegas: Last night, Vance headlined a Vegas fundraiser for Trump’s MAGA Inc. super PAC that required a donation of $1 million per attendee, WaPo’s Natalie Allison reports.

  
Did you know Playbook goes beyond the newsletter—with powerhouse new co-hosts at the mic? Tune in to The Playbook Podcast every weekday for exclusive intel and sharp analysis on Trump’s Washington, straight from Jack Blanchard and Dasha Burns. Start listening now.
    
2026 WATCH

FIRST IN PLAYBOOK: Earlier this year, Musk was “growing tired” of Vivek Ramaswamy and telephoned Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine with a request, POLITICO’s Jonathan Martin reports this morning: appoint Ramaswamy to the Senate seat vacated by Vance. DeWine demurred, of course, and Ramaswamy threw in for the 2026 gubernatorial race. And that means that DeWine now faces an unlikely coda to his long career in politics: He’s likely to either be succeeded by Ramaswamy, or by his own longtime Democratic rival, Sherrod Brown, who is considering a run for governor.

But but but: There could be a way to avoid that fate: Enter Jim Tressel, the former Ohio State football coach, whom DeWine named lieutenant governor after appointing the sitting LG, Jon Husted, to the Senate, and who is now facing down a potential gubernatorial candidate of his own. Can the coach pull off the upset and beat Ramaswamy? The challenge is, as JMart writes, that “Tressel is a Mike DeWine guy in a Donald Trump party.”

SPEAKING OF COACHES: Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-Ala.) announced yesterday that he is running for governor, immediately catapulting the former Auburn football coach to frontrunner status in the race, writes AL.com’s Mike Cason. But the decision also sets up an open Senate race in the midterms, POLITICO’s Ali Bianco notes.

MEANWHILE, IN MICHIGAN: The 2026 jockeying is in full swing at the Detroit Regional Chamber’s Mackinac Policy Conference, with Senate and gubernatorial hopefuls working the well-connected crowds on the Island. Playbook’s Zack Stanton writes in that much of the buzz last night surrounded new polling from the Glengariff Group posing head-to-head matchups in the state’s marquee statewide 2026 races.

Notable among the results … Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan’s independent bid for governor is polling north of 20 percent statewide — despite his low name ID outside of metro Detroit. “If you had told me I was in the 20s this early, I wouldn’t have believed you,” Duggan told Zack. He sees a path to victory in pulling equally from both parties (which, indeed, the polling suggested he is) en route to 40 percent of the vote. The former longtime Democrat believes he can appeal to a segment of Trump voters who “want to shake up the system,” but “without the nastiness … [or] divisive language.”

  BEGIN-REGION Playbook3   
A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:



The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act is positive for homeownership and the middle class. Learn more.
    END-REGION 
BEST OF THE REST

DANCE OF THE SUPERPOWERS: Following the ramped-up tariffs, U.S. companies report a spike in fraudulent activities from Chinese companies trying to avoid taxes, NYT’s Ana Swanson and Lazaro Gamio report. Chinese shipping companies are offering ways to evade duties by “altering the information about the shipments that is given to the U.S. government to qualify for a lower tariff rate,” executives and officials say. … Chip giant Nvidia will report Q1 earnings after the close of business today and investors are likely to “look for definitive answers on how much U.S. chip curbs on China will cost the company,” Reuters’ Arsheeya Bajwa previews.

FULL COURT PRESS: The Trump administration is pushing the Supreme Court to lift U.S. District Judge Brian Murphy’s order blocking the administration’s plans for expedited deportations to countries where immigrants “have no previous ties,” POLITICO’s Josh Gerstein reports. “The federal government argued that Murphy has stalled its efforts to carry out deportations of migrants who can’t be returned to their home countries,” AP’s Rebecca Santana and Lindsay Whitehurst report.

Coming attractions: The appeal is just one of many the high court has faced from the White House in recent months. And SCOTUS is facing a series of hotly debated topics as the justices turn “toward issuing a flurry of opinions through the end of June,” CNN’s John Fritze reports. Still, they must contend with “more than a dozen emergency appeals tied to Trump’s second term, including cases dealing with mass firings, immigration and the president’s efforts to end birthright citizenship,” with more to come even once they break.

More court reads: “Judge tosses Trump order punishing the law firm WilmerHale,” by WaPo’s Mark Berman: “U.S. District Judge Richard J. Leon ruled that Trump’s order was unconstitutional and blocked the government from enforcing it, becoming the third judge this month to side with a law firm that had challenged the president’s orders. … A ruling in the case of the fourth firm, Susman Godfrey, is still pending, though a judge has temporarily blocked most of Trump’s penalties for that business.”

  
Policy moves fast—stay ahead with POLITICO’s Policy Intelligence Assistant. Effortlessly search POLITICO's archive of 1M+ news articles, analysis documents, and legislative text. Track legislation, showcase your impact, and generate custom reports in seconds. Designed for POLITICO Pro subscribers, this tool helps you make faster, smarter decisions. Start exploring now.
     TALK OF THE TOWN
PLAYBOOK METRO SECTION — The Metro is launching its tap-to-pay upgrade at a ceremony at Dulles later today. Commuters can now pay for their rides right at the turnstile by tapping their phone, credit card or debit card. More from the Washingtonian

FIRST IN PLAYBOOK — 314 Action has added Bri Gillis as a campaign adviser for federal and statewide candidates, Eden Giagnorio as comms director and Tara Saye as deputy development director.

TRANSITIONS — Cheyenne Hunt is now executive director of Gen-Z for Change. She previously was a big tech accountability advocate at Public Citizen and is an Amy Klobuchar alum. … Patrick Lohmeyer is now VP of international network programs and partnerships at United Way Worldwide. He most recently was CEO at LINC. … Chris Crawford will be senior director of civil strategies at Interfaith America. He currently is a policy strategist of free and fair elections at Protect Democracy.

… Kaylin Dines is now chief of staff for Rep. Brittany Pettersen (D-Colo.). She most recently was press secretary and senior adviser for communications at OPM in the Biden administration and is a Yadira Caraveo and Tim Ryan alum. … Emma Mears is now head of membership development at Ned’s Club. She previously was membership and community manager. And Jenna Groesch is now head of membership at Ned’s Club. She previously was membership executive at the Club’s New York location.

ENGAGED — Ted Scheinman, senior editor at Smithsonian, and Tara Ganapathy, counsel in the congressional investigations practice at K&L Gates and a Biden OMB and HHS alum, got engaged on Monday. They met in 2019 and reconnected because their respective interns were friends. He proposed in a park near their house, after hollowing out a portion of the Warren Report and hiding the ring box in there. Pic

WEDDING — Chris Ringer, legislative director for Rep. Sheri Biggs (R-S.C.), and Alexus Gutierrez, an intelligence analyst at the Defense Department and a Brian Fitzpatrick alum, recently got married in Charleston, South Carolina. The couple met on Capitol Hill in fall 2018. Pic

HAPPY BIRTHDAY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio … Rep. April McClain Delaney (D-Md.) … Rudy Giuliani … Jessica Anderson of the Sentinel Action Fund … Natalie Yezbick of Sen. John Cornyn’s (R-Texas) office … Mark Greenbaum of Rep. Nellie Pou’s (D-N.J.) office … POLITICO’s Alana Cunningham … Lauren Mandelker … The 19th’s Emily Ramshaw … Andy Stone of Meta … WaPo’s Pradnya (P.J.) Joshi … Lisa Wallenda Picard … Global Business Alliance’s Jessica Cahill … Chris Downing … Uber’s Josh Gold … Julie Hershey Carr … Herald Group’s Colin Hensel … Edelman Smithfield’s Chris Donahoe ... Robb Harleston … TSA’s Brian Kelly … former Reps. Steve King (R-Iowa), Scott Rigell (R-Va.) and Tom Petri (R-Wis.) … Christy Felling … Marty Kramer … Katharine Weymouth … Matt Orr of Rep. Russell Fry’s (R-S.C.) office … Adelle Nazarian … Thorn Run’s Greg Lankler

Did someone forward this email to you? Sign up here.

Send Playbookers tips to playbook@politico.com or text us on Signal here. Playbook couldn’t happen without our editor Zack Stanton, deputy editor Garrett Ross and Playbook Podcast producer Callan Tansill-Suddath.

  BEGIN-REGION Playbook4   
A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:

The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act is positive for homeownership and the middle class. A recent survey commissioned by the National Association of REALTORS® shows strong, bipartisan voter support for key provisions in the bill that make housing more affordable. From extending lower tax rates and SALT relief to incentives for small businesses and community investment, this bill delivers real benefits that will strengthen the American Dream and help build resilient communities. However, there is still more bipartisan work to be done to bring down the cost of housing. Learn more.
    END-REGION

Dasha Burns @DashaBurns

>The Conversation </i
>with <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Dasha Burns </strong
>arrives on Sunday, June 1 — and <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.CGacIBOYSgYF-WIXrlhk8FP1Vr1ZFRhGzIVXwzZjtsNIzoe3JwpvZ_Jr7ct6KDRl/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h4/h001.uSOZ7TatDRFCqJQfmDubtaPEgTWiXMILrnG8tSQmh_M" target="_blank">we’re dropping a first look</a
>. Each week on her new podcast, Dasha will sit down with one of the most compelling — and sometimes unexpected — power players in Washington. This isn’t just a podcast. It’s a new kind of political interview show for a moment when politics feels more personal, more chaotic and more consequential than ever. Catch the video and audio trailer out this morning to see what Dasha’s digging into this season. And subscribe to <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dGU6vEH-V4r3GBLPJaoxDlJehi_2BWihwUtqjZLBhEa71HgDQe5u7aP1-AK4d_97QAHEUodhr7VUkTPGNKCBTTVqDXmTPwNEgJFoXqRhjrl5KyOBLieLwlGYnu3fUHfp/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h5/h001.Lw407UDjWmktMsfAkbQo2dtn48VsfcXcQqKuObIefSk" target="_blank">the podcast</a
>, wherever you listen or watch.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">And yes … </strong
>You can still catch Dasha Monday through Thursday mornings <i
>as well,</i
> on the Playbook Podcast with yours truly. You don’t get rid of us that easy.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">In today’s Playbook …</strong
></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">—</strong
></span> The president takes a media hiatus ... but fear not! We’ll always have his socials.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">—</strong
></span> Vance and the Trump boys go full crypto-bro in Vegas.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">—</strong
></span> Why gubernatorials are currently the races to watch.<br></p></td>
                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding-bottom:10px; min-width:100%; width:100%;">
    <table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" role="presentation" style="background-color:#121522; min-width:100%;">
        <tbody>
        <tr>
            <td width="32" valign="middle" style="vertical-align:top;font-size:0;text-align:right;padding-top:10px;"><img src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/origin-static.politico.com/hosted/icon-red-circle%402x.png" title="" alt="" width="12" style="max-width:12px;margin-top:1px;"></td>
            <td style="text-align:left;font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:12px;color:#FFFFFF;text-transform:uppercase;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:2px;padding-top:10px;padding-bottom:10px;padding-left:10px;margin:0;" valign="middle">DRIVING THE DAY</td>
        </tr>

    </table>
</td>
                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"></td>
                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p align="center" style="margin:0 0 20px 0;"><img src="https://www.politico.com/dims4/default/8ffc5bd/2147483647/resize/1000x/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fstatic.politico.com%2Fc7%2F85%2Fcf0f38364e1787d1f6912d7d33ec%2Ftrump-74523.jpg" title="Trump" alt="President Donald Trump bows his head in prayer with others, before delivering the Memorial Day Address at the 157th National Memorial Day Observance at Arlington National Cemetery, Monday, May 26, 2025, in Arlington, Va." width="500" style="width:100%;max-width:500px;"></p><p style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:12px;color:#6E7381;margin-bottom:24px;">A quick trawl through the archives suggests President Donald Trump has done media on 111 of his 138 days back in office.  |  Julia Demaree Nikhinson/AP Photo</p></td>
                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">THE SOUND OF SILENCE:</strong
> By lunchtime today it will have been 48 hours since <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Donald Trump </strong
>stepped in front of a TV camera for a speech or Q&A — <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>the first time that’s happened</i
></strong
> (outside of the weekends) since he returned to the White House on Jan. 20. Whatever your politics, that’s a remarkable record of public availability, especially when compared to his famously sheltered predecessor. <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV67uHtca8Q1l9qwJW2jARkJL0I_sLKMLEH6bCYicxWtF4u_HX-4uo6skd3r0U_gRZKQTQJ7E0WXj7yivKbaoNxM9bIwW3qIQ_RQDX2utqrqkQzaSstd8W2xXsRHESlfFSUw/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h6/h001.W8XXuR2BlbsSeMBJNNT905_YzZaHw108lP49hS5Q8ZA" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>And look how that turned out.</i
></strong
></a
></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">By the numbers: </strong
>A quick trawl through the archives suggests Trump 2.0 has done media on 111 of his 138 days back in office — an 80 percent hit rate that <i
>includes weekends </i
>and must put him on course to being just about the most-accessible president in modern history. And aside from the <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKP6B7k0A8Lo57NWsGrvI97INj1m7obSHJuN1fbPT_SbMlQA7G6yjYz_ArdybSeHR1tSp71VEcYbczJGeyo9OCn2cAtijS2rcI8S4I0IDRnhifpy8ta9iIFX1LCjiLO56Og/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h7/h001.NSFX3h367uNXURoGtytoZDXmMz2E5Jv2yaiue_MAorg" target="_blank">lamentable attempt to ban AP,</a
> he’s basically taken questions from all-comers. It’s impressive stuff.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>And it matters:</i
></strong
> In case anyone still needs this hammering home for them, the <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Joe Biden </strong
>experience shows just how important it is that leaders are held up to regular scrutiny. Trump’s answers may sometimes be rambling, erratic — or even downright unpleasant — but every American voter can see where he’s at.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">So why the sudden silence?</strong
> Trump has no scheduled media appearances today, for the second-consecutive day — though it’s still possible a <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">2 p.m.</strong
> closed-doors “executive order” session turns into one of his freeform Q&As. Either way, no one thinks he’s shirking. Aides tell my Playbook colleague <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Dasha Burns</strong
> Trump spent yesterday holding calls and meetings in the Oval Office, and on this morning’s Playbook Podcast she predicts we’re likely just witnessing the calm before the next storm.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Storm watch:</strong
> We’re still expecting a big announcement on Iran as soon as this week — <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV64bdYmMUM90y4Dz49LTdagtowTmmjq5Mis5e0Fuic7sYNQPq2XjWDdv_ZRqXxKWjSv1S-kvcXhiCqT45C84TGXjm0cD5uqoq7gVbb_hzppdO6_91HdMnvbDqeIupeJPPezJbQhn1K9XN4IOc66t6b8vSXzWtb7Q1qwdBWZ00LkYb/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h8/h001.lRUOUf7ICARTwGKgqjTTY_sDqxDIQZEfp4NK94Kh5W0" target="_blank">the NYT reports</a
> this would be a “declaration of some common principles” rather than a fully fledged nuclear deal — and Russia sanctions may or may not be in the offing, with Trump <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV69rXRyiWqhCzIJbstXnYrx4_LxbcTeoTjhVytxcP0_2VD3Tgeu512tV15-DgzNHUBRTjfPk4A1P8kjNjc93RxcTqkW8AThmceblWYzWIb7Oj6kt8UZJ3s0qPqaPMAN5-IQ/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h9/h001.OZ2gnExFCNE03aLq6X-wybcvwyP8FLWgMqMwlGj4Rbo" target="_blank">lashing out</a
> at President <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Vladimir Putin</strong
> again yesterday … <i
>Everybody </i
>is praying for some sort of breakthrough on Gaza, especially after the <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV64bdYmMUM90y4Dz49LTdaguPLfJBbcYZWWoPxJMmEbh527QA-1G9SGmJlQzu-8GM1mmEgnCMQBGfR7pgVDvcZRgn1nT8I2jnWhbJip7G9gMm/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h10/h001.O70LSnaxk_07TxWR56NSO6kSVoyYymFv9Q9RDr8KDyU" target="_blank">aid chaos</a
> we saw yesterday … And the whole ‘war on Harvard’ thing doesn’t appear to be losing any steam. Trump has posted about the Ivy League university multiple times on Truth Social the past few days.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Speaking of Truth Social:</strong
> Close observers may have noticed that Trump’s innate — <i
>how can we put this kindly?</i
> — <i
>desire to be heard </i
>has rather spilled out on social media during his brief MSM hiatus. Aside from the memes, reposts and videos that always pepper his feed, Trump posted nine genuine messages yesterday, another nine on Monday and eight on Sunday ... Which averages out about once every couple of hours, after you’ve factored in sleep. (If indeed, the president does sleep.)</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">What’s on Trump’s mind: </strong
><a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMFqmdDcvFKfSzFqXH_5GcBTEnkXx3_zxqgs_HlqQNOQE/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h11/h001.E3h-AmxC2jb7ZUy-Q3Ja2f7smhB62_GawZQn8MSQqEs" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Fannie Mae and Fannie Mac</i
></strong
></a
> … <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMljF1PSUKNK2x4w0n4IA8u__07iML_DownawLchkGrJ0/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h12/h001.DO1BZ3QsYFQjBwRKiTz5aaYdSmxCz7Cwy3zd9MXuYrI" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Biden and the autopen</i
></strong
></a
> <i
>…</i
> <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMsB5df6NCbpO0efRx2PK46z1xrPJ6ZqKeelXLqviMosc/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h13/h001.wbu_vxthN0wRA5TId33j5RpuRn0CmIXFTlTyNXI-pmg" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Jobs in Alaska</i
></strong
></a
> <i
>…</i
> <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMrstyHzTj37bPcjOKA6zMhFhq8ATAV5-K21QkNyXLaQE/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h14/h001.5a3elNaw9gTNfOSptBf-L_LbJqPV12DKfMrhNM-P7jY" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Fishing in Maine</i
></strong
></a
> <i
>…</i
> <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXM7SSGJzFnkx1aE0ViMBhVUaqzDLDmVmObqcg-EcevTTs/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h15/h001.GMinpKuUhSismnjcXpIojD7RHTvaWV28IasO4YRNEn4" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Canada becoming the “51st state”</i
></strong
></a
> … <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMGrWt4fUoAe1zC-hp7Lwlo9jUjm1PpcbZnGjBGj3ZGAY/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h16/h001.orpUwEZ1oB6VC1PzEYhuJfQm_yl9xB2BKJJGHlrtDfU" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Border Patrol</i
></strong
></a
> … <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMedlI1WZ5W-9pIEveStmxu5oE2jHpzRjSoCC5Vp246Fk/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h17/h001.CWTzJ1I9nPg17yekMtERXLyXRbfvhYv3V0LWCPjqgS8" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Putin</i
></strong
></a
> … <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMuAuNyep_1BANv_63bTy_eHL_mgNlELty_MfqseyppJA/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h18/h001.whQckZlimyGoU-9efUUSr5MZzWfngbm3CJif7dhXyUM" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Tariffs on Europe</i
></strong
></a
> … <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMfQDNQLyUfP3wsb5_jtqoVB0ESX5XmLwuTEim1J4z7zc/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h19/h001.AiXjIzHkBHd1SykEH241EF1J884gguriu0itAVBS-PU" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>California athletics</i
></strong
></a
> … And that was just <i
>yesterday</i
>. Silence is not quite the right word for where we’re at.<br></p></td>
                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td>

  <tr>
   <td height="15" style="height:15px; font-size:0; border-top:1px solid #E5E7EB;"> </td>

  <tr>
   <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;background-color:#ffffff;">
    <p style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:12px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:10px;color:#000000;">A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:</p>
    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:20px;line-height:24px;color:#000000;">The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act is positive for homeownership and the middle class, with strong bipartisan voter backing. Key provisions—like lower tax rates, SALT relief, and incentives for small businesses and community investment—make housing more affordable and strengthen communities and the American Dream. While this bill brings real benefits, more bipartisan action is needed to reduce housing costs. <a href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKCJCpfzLXKLU6KDtDs6qCfYrBryUczlVs2Z-c50x2vJlZoSTr-eb1G2LNIhv3nwB6sNkElUlPqen4J8lxwoJgS5OSN3zdbZ4_7l75A3dATHIII6cEaDgy9JZbGx14AzfEMIMwSN1ThRqFki1mNCCx6E/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h20/h001.AcLXaRLdtxYTuH3n7ci1j17lJGOqQmdrKWI2VbK-G2M" target="_blank" style="text-decoration:underline;color:#007bc7;">Learn more.</a></p></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td height="20" style="height:20px; font-size:0; border-top:1px solid #E5E7EB;"> </td>
  </tr>
 </tbody>
</table></td>

                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Nevertheless:</strong
> It does feel like at least some of the relentless, minute-by-minute drama of Trump’s first months back in power has started to fade. <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Elon Musk’</strong
>s all-consuming DOGE project feels much less significant since its principle character slinked back to the world of tech. Trump’s market-wobbling tariff wars have become a series of snarled-up trade talks. The Ukraine war looks intractable. Mass deportations have been hampered by limited resources and the courts. Those of us covering the White House can actually take a quick breath.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">And speaking of Musk …</strong
> Filling the Trump-shaped void this morning is none other than Musk himself, now reverting back to his former tech-geek persona after tanking Tesla’s image (and value) with his brief sojourn into politics. Flaunting an “Occupy Mars” T-shirt rather than a MAGA hat <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV6wzH62Rc9P4qcO39WcxLMDdC67NIIHzNmGPE4ORmrFU217umuw3hHgiLtBfYVhc6ZA/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h21/h001.z039an5joRA2bXxh7fAeXZ-X_PQQNGm9LxP49zuV_eg" target="_blank">in an interview with CBS</a
>, Musk seeks to put some clear blue water between himself and the GOP by criticising the budget passed by the House.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Regrets, I’ve had a few:</strong
> Musk also did a <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV69rXRyiWqhCzIJbstXnYrx78QE4bAo8b2G0_0hviJYsy_a-M3vHxrx0ywe4FFhXhEFf2Jwy1NxLsXyR0OEeAlesdH7dcxWPgqogLJKHGnnkz/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h22/h001.B7v1NRsDndXIxG1BC97-LRBpM3JkCRbKIHPJXZDgLY0" target="_blank">sit-down with WaPo</a
>, in which he laments the reputational damage caused by his chainsaw-wielding work for the White House. “DOGE is just becoming the whipping boy for everything,” Musk complained. “Something bad would happen anywhere, and we would get blamed for it even if we had nothing to do with it.” Sympathy levels within the federal government will be pretty low.<br></p></td>
                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td>
<table width="100%">
 <tbody>
  <tr>
   <td height="15" style="height:15px; font-size:0; border-top:1px solid #E5E7EB;"> </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;background-color:#FFFFFF;">
    <p style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:12px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:10px;color:#000000;">A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:</p>
    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height:15px;"><a href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKCJCpfzLXKLU6KDtDs6qCfYrBryUczlVs2Z-c50x2vJl3IB7QBQo4IS8crlRAS7whODXS-n2vZpkDvz5MisDZrnZW8f319nFe0vICU6RykdbBrwD6XGv89HVCKGIuCfjTrYMFo07vKx3T2fjOXgl3bE/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h23/h001.3Ox0xDdZHQWair65cNCLkSKOLCLBVo1MnFAgw04qJnk" target="_blank"><img src="https://www.politico.com/dims4/default/2a76915/2147483647/resize/1000x/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fstatic.politico.com%2F45%2F8f%2F6bf509e448b0a25ae7ec22e7a5a6%2Fmwfsun500x125-1.jpg" title="Advertisement Image" alt="Advertisement Image" border="0" width="500" style="width:100%;max-width:500px;"></a> <img src="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/ad/N7384.146504POLITICO0/B33683778.421820684;sz=1x1;ord=[timestamp]" border="0" a></p>
    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:20px;line-height:24px;color:#000000;">The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act supports the middle class with broad voter support for provisions that boost housing affordability, community investment, and small businesses. <a href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKCJCpfzLXKLU6KDtDs6qCfYrBryUczlVs2Z-c50x2vJlSWqrcvXA6rMFVt2PqeqcjhxlimXjRP8rHgdjz2C9M_k81v-15uVYS1Lp2TsUD5annL4Jr3nnrD_HsHj6o_jK0mjJgphsCgCqFynN3aJcvdg/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h24/h001.9b_taAGRV_T063n7adxBi0ddV8VOltngTBvTDhzuGJ0" target="_blank" style="text-decoration:underline;color:#007BC7;">Learn more.</a></p></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td height="20" style="height:20px; font-size:0; border-top:1px solid #E5E7EB;"> </td>
  </tr>
 </tbody>
</table></td>

                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">COINING IT IN</strong
></span></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">TRUMP’S CRYPTO PLAY:</strong
> Unusually, the biggest political event in the diary this morning is happening in <i
>Las Vegas</i
>, where the astonishing overlap between Trump’s political and personal interests will again be on display.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">First, the political …</strong
> At <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">12 noon</strong
> Eastern, VP <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">JD Vance </strong
>will deliver the keynote address at the Bitcoin 2025 Conference in Vegas, setting out the administration’s full-speed-ahead approach to the U.S. crypto industry. It’s the same conference <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKP6B7k0A8Lo57NWsGrvI97IMVMTMDCdOvhA9qSswfHLnSSo4zspTFjjfM1qlH4gGCHgzrqFQ4n_eZOhAtqx4zSFjNaPDHZCE8toGL9MQ_bBHqqLdXGkQ33mWIvOK3UHG4WJGqkclxdOs1WTrykD_Vk0/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h25/h001.zSKaNmV2TPhp4rvE_mRC-4hxg4n0a-T0SqCJbUSlR98" target="_blank">Trump headlined in person last year</a
>, promising America would become a “bitcoin superpower” under his leadership. He’s certainly been true to his word, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV60NaQ4rVI4Zyu4yJsvLhxy2De_rCZ-_EhLQUJuSuypxuQU1zs5La0AZuGXbno29aMugKWRr51LmskkC38V4GFIsdJh8fVJBEVweaZZTowMU_xY2EDUCPVBFx_VUzGcH9mQ/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h26/h001.Q-eVPuEBHvpmxK6w-1DYIxZwbAEyqfqtBHd5O3VsCj0" target="_blank">per CNBC</a
>.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Then, the personal … </strong
>At <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">4:30 p.m.</strong
>, Trump’s sons <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Eric</strong
> and <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Donald Trump Jr.</strong
> will speak at the very same conference in Vegas. It’s presumably an industry they feel invested in, given they back a major Bitcoin venture themselves, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV64_yG7snWAffRT9BYG1rZJy_JK0boVntm6P0EWMWPP-wNmoYfNbN1o_9t_prTXwV3esyLoWW4rJJalwHcAAEWHH6wy1Fw-D6qjrdEgq6xlQzE5sf3rVaRLr5Y_1ytN40w8Zd9daxLxcm4yR7iPux378/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h27/h001.9queiJ5DXy5QFroBPZ0-ALEkBI00lupqUCeBKs9uEmA" target="_blank">per Reuters</a
>. And it comes just a day after a separate family-linked business, the Trump Media & Technology Group, announced <i
>its </i
>intention to raise <i
>$2.5 billion </i
>to invest in bitcoin, as <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV68DkcOgpKJhncvf49dlM8zlxpK8dWkFKZ3R1DgvRQ7W-PJMS4Pu_x8IUylClOjtWox4e2MXpQWUaEsfWIv3Qb4hIqXyGl3ttDcMAXPHnEH0fRD2__HViixVei7YcQjDjRQ/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h28/h001.z0mbd0jdLkj3Y7ImuMyN-viDy-K7s69hZ6s-zYmagZk" target="_blank">WSJ’s Alexander Osipovich and Jennifer Calfas report</a
>. And that in turn came after Trump offered out exclusive VIP dinner invites to the 220 top buyers of his personal $Trump memecoin, as an incentive to buy more stock. It’s all head-spinning stuff for a president of the United States.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">More news from Vegas:</strong
> Coinbase chief policy officer <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Faryar Shirzad</strong
> announced yesterday that the cryptocurrency exchange will be a “major sponsor” of America250, the Trump-affiliated committee organizing celebrations of the 250th birthday for the U.S. And this isn’t Coinbase's first donation to a Trump committee, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.zmXQYxftKFWCpJXVm9O1dtkWOa61pAAiG7-nKBJrzYzG-agvSRA6lDw0Hve2yMQOU2i6W51IGF32l9gnO4-HDg/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h29/h001.np-7Y2lXeULr-se8s8Qw4PUfWAhTg49nV4FN6FGHQr4" target="_blank">notes The Verge’s Tina Nguyen</a
>. It “previously donated $1 million to Trump’s inauguration committee,” she writes on X. “The SEC dropped a lawsuit against Coinbase a month later.”</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>And a P.S. from Vegas:</i
></strong
> Last night, Vance headlined a Vegas fundraiser for Trump’s MAGA Inc. super PAC that required a donation of <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>$1 million per attendee</i
></strong
>, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV69rXRyiWqhCzIJbstXnYrx4_LxbcTeoTjhVytxcP0_2V48EhMBBVXF_rFP9gjFsr-QOZunFHkHXT9B1KnsTWhFxWlXjbBlVdM4Mho3Xo-1pil40zDARTkYY7YdZkyIgEnw/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h30/h001.Y0EzNfKdrN3RNFtGh0Dc1a8wmo6sIJfYSSw1eV5Jqhg" target="_blank">WaPo’s Natalie Allison reports</a
>.<br></p></td>
                    </tr>

</tr><tr>

></strong
>

                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">2026 WATCH</strong
></span></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">FIRST IN PLAYBOOK:</strong
></span> Earlier this year, Musk was “growing tired” of <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Vivek Ramaswamy</strong
> and telephoned Ohio Gov. <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Mike DeWine</strong
> with a request, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV65ZWHEH5gWGSDKLrcKzwr396MPjho3G2zOoP4i1NAyC2qR6xVGzynUHhVHX9vEtmXZzhwBpsYORW1oXxLdiIXm-cyLCdNoWI-GDpy95-i9s7vxNfaO1XwhMnP_s91jb_PmIYtgNZJ9jLzJRm0ehwN-hoqefXHiQV9cGwI40DxAZAgKJVh-xRdV2VrtiaSkYYqQM5HFaX4hh6EuqCwj_xLpDn5MsJ59l-g9o0CGYEISfy__FJWLJkZTJnvgxLC-6prfeM9CFOUthfOeKOADA2PJk/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h33/h001.Wy8W8FFIxrk2NxbDz436oK7t-kpMUvyb-Z_fKKkem1I" target="_blank">POLITICO’s Jonathan Martin reports this morning</a
>: appoint Ramaswamy to the Senate seat vacated by Vance. DeWine demurred, of course, and Ramaswamy threw in for the 2026 gubernatorial race. And that means that DeWine now faces an unlikely coda to his long career in politics: He’s likely to either be succeeded by Ramaswamy, or by his own longtime Democratic rival, <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Sherrod Brown</strong
>, who is considering a run for governor.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">But but but:</strong
> There could be a way to avoid that fate: Enter <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Jim Tressel</strong
>, the former Ohio State football coach, whom DeWine named lieutenant governor after appointing the sitting LG, <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Jon Husted</strong
>, to the Senate, and who is now facing down a potential gubernatorial candidate of his own. Can the coach pull off the upset and beat Ramaswamy? The challenge is, as JMart writes, that “Tressel is a Mike DeWine guy in a Donald Trump party.”</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">SPEAKING OF COACHES: </strong
>Sen.<strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"> Tommy Tuberville</strong
> (R-Ala.) announced yesterday that he is running for governor, immediately catapulting the former Auburn football coach to frontrunner status in the race, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV6w25MO3FwbuZnRZS6x9hEV3VJRqw0DPm_gJodMvW3739dTYDIZyIYCVfqBhPqWF-iEda7XMNao8Z5Nvrq8I0UWas5galeGwYuvwyC2Ogw43RVevHbYQBrKB3RobNGNhMZJrkgUwm_8ATZz7Az4Rmrf8/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h34/h001.M_5G7bEDOEWJOqNd2umVwaDVYFlkpov1UxdhIkuNr1Q" target="_blank">writes AL.com’s Mike Cason</a
>. But the decision also sets up an open Senate race in the midterms, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV65ZWHEH5gWGSDKLrcKzwr3-3nc9BABKSkMt8osi9MRaaGrkYkTeZ-u2HdmbaAI_PovqJ_-U3xmetuimwMlgmB9EYPDOTLXG45ApsAl-VCvcnAPkeMOOdQvAXv31IJiYbRmmUB7lbhpbUg4J-DqBUN63RzohjlYX1o8j1FGNfvW0-qIszziQMKfTmVfNRwiy-UjDvEiaywHDNkeIrOlLzbNa8i_NJ_PRjK5RkS3fHcNVK/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h35/h001.R7m3cNI4nHlSbai7K-OwyPbnYGkC6GHw2SaQElI9qb8" target="_blank">POLITICO’s Ali Bianco notes</a
>.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">MEANWHILE, IN MICHIGAN:</strong
> The 2026 jockeying is in full swing at the Detroit Regional Chamber’s Mackinac Policy Conference, with Senate and gubernatorial hopefuls working the well-connected crowds on the Island. Playbook’s Zack Stanton writes in that much of the buzz last night surrounded new polling from the <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV67pxXEpvVsrh3lJ5CjJhGnS_K4ygbiwLf3QpiP3dIwKdywDFXWD8LvICw89V2H9yXhwuq8oOd3F0B1-thLzZWxiIBtL9PvAMZ3O9v6GSGvDMLRNKliCBGuUtFjxX5uU6qSgjT8LuIdnL-RME2ozlcaEyVC4mm19IxIy0NRS_pmEa/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h36/h001.KSvoWaPmpSARz7xM4VtU4_NLzV3FNgOxgo561N8SUzw" target="_blank">Glengariff Group posing head-to-head matchups</a
> in the state’s marquee statewide 2026 races.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Notable among the results …</strong
> Detroit Mayor <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Mike Duggan’s</strong
> independent bid for governor is polling north of 20 percent statewide — despite his low name ID outside of metro Detroit. “If you had told me I was in the 20s this early, I wouldn’t have believed you,” Duggan told Zack. He sees a path to victory in pulling equally from both parties (which, indeed, the polling suggested he is) en route to 40 percent of the vote. The former longtime Democrat believes he can appeal to a segment of Trump voters who “want to shake up the system,” but “without the nastiness … [or] divisive language.”<br></p></td>
                    </tr>

    <p style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:12px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:10px;color:#000000;">A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:</p>
    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height:15px;"><a href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKCJCpfzLXKLU6KDtDs6qCfYrBryUczlVs2Z-c50x2vJli_ODUdpgTS84eEygi4F3hHG5OgdPtYOUNa7B9RK6v3FaYL0h2J2cC5N3noiZ0Xt9ULvfWRunSXm4EK1d_U4kyoFU8h7BfWPw0fstn1a_oHs/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h37/h001.wEaKTRTnMawgxZ7plI0sS-dwsSoIXtMvPoJ560-WWZQ" target="_blank"><img src="https://www.politico.com/dims4/default/db4b7af/2147483647/resize/1000x/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fstatic.politico.com%2F72%2F8c%2Fa18a0aae44adba9a224797efad3c%2Fmwfsun500x500-1.jpg" title="Advertisement Image" alt="Advertisement Image" border="0" width="500" style="width:100%;max-width:500px;"></a> <img src="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/ad/N7384.146504POLITICO0/B33683778.421820741;sz=1x1;ord=[timestamp]" border="0" a></p>
    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:20px;line-height:24px;color:#000000;">The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act is positive for homeownership and the middle class. <a href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKCJCpfzLXKLU6KDtDs6qCfYrBryUczlVs2Z-c50x2vJlWHu0sEt71N4-uK4ssK6I8kiqe6mZD8hCPsNEs7vlVeCbTnnLS4SDJaenR9kqq2aHv8W8cEO_Jmi4U2nySNWUihGDiydhht4PQ6l1zL4I-O4/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h38/h001.x_GSLXAYX85Hs6JzcUW46kO7IqKkK5VyM2QPDHOS0-c" target="_blank" style="text-decoration:underline;color:#007BC7;">Learn more.</a></p></td>
  </tr>

   <td height="20" style="height:20px; font-size:0; border-top:1px solid #E5E7EB;"> </td>

                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">BEST OF THE REST</strong
></span></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">DANCE OF THE SUPERPOWERS:</strong
> Following the ramped-up tariffs, U.S. companies report a spike in fraudulent activities from Chinese companies trying to avoid taxes, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV64bdYmMUM90y4Dz49LTdagtEF3JHXIPbauePzk3KiMt8Nvk9A1KLTOu_uCdTeciN0OWYWhVT_CwAM5CGKSLnqV5Q4pGubpi-YOWG31FXdEap/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h39/h001.Q4KELd80c_CViExVafxDaY3mRG10fnOpbsB12sDHkWc" target="_blank">NYT’s Ana Swanson and Lazaro Gamio report</a
>. Chinese shipping companies are offering ways to evade duties by “altering the information about the shipments that is given to the U.S. government to qualify for a lower tariff rate,” executives and officials say. … Chip giant Nvidia will report Q1 earnings after the close of business today and investors are likely to “look for definitive answers on how much U.S. chip curbs on China will cost the company,” <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV6ybcmhjoEsFvVpqTYRiaPpTW6wsAELv5YNXktS5IgOBNLKUXzwFGkpyIvoLMaiGD59ZnBeXUWAi9lZLpdeBklA9gGur5bkNWC5mSHYuflo931VM7RfUZXtq_RMzuVoqJtQ/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h40/h001.ZX1lWmgIrGPfnzWDmj7HgC0A1BMqvv1nBsp3v3PmxSc" target="_blank">Reuters’ Arsheeya Bajwa previews</a
>.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">FULL COURT PRESS: </strong
>The Trump administration is pushing the Supreme Court to lift U.S. District Judge <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Brian Murphy’s</strong
> order blocking the administration’s plans for expedited deportations to countries where immigrants “have no previous ties,” <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV65ZWHEH5gWGSDKLrcKzwr3-3nc9BABKSkMt8osi9MRaaykKIUw9j0_fae8ADvvj1mNAL1ZxsEAgAiGlcVP6Ua5dJCgtn4dNuNcktazB_SA0cMRity0vE3NCg33ZPwxV2ccnp96kQgqeNaZVjKcM9ViM2dZ3uL7yiRS0WGmwNdfiXpv3mD4ZW1yppSGL4u45UgPeSfmNafDyQd6QgjPbGdPZYH5reUGo7NR8jv1kRjjhtAMbEstYym2TFKqHCLjkzwQ/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h41/h001.-L5tUXHkydDv45LxlfsoNH4Wl6ywB6wyvYJBB9t1EM4" target="_blank">POLITICO’s Josh Gerstein reports</a
>. “The federal government argued that Murphy has stalled its efforts to carry out deportations of migrants who can’t be returned to their home countries,” <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKP6B7k0A8Lo57NWsGrvI97I6u_Tot3wtzOA2ip0vJBMODGROpNhqjd7BcYGdx_uqh1ox3ISIwP05ZQm7-Bswq0hr4WrByn0GLYSpU-PUeG-6T3bmvSci8b8RpE5ixm_383ACq1h-9v7JWZnwBqosNCYKDnz3ytPtHbwjgB9qFsuP/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h42/h001.8xxh3a4KG032luGpH4HLVwy1z-Hh3TSwEn4mP0S1E1U" target="_blank">AP’s Rebecca Santana and Lindsay Whitehurst report</a
>.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Coming attractions:</strong
> The appeal is just one of many the high court has faced from the White House in recent months. And SCOTUS is facing a series of hotly debated topics as the justices turn “toward issuing a flurry of opinions through the end of June,” <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV6y0EOrtyfGMsER1RJbqTH_Jg89_D10BJSUeaEJJt4DYgFsqlVaMbNdSWbOGQr1YyLB67MvprRtFo7coPvRvVQtWpgJesZN78ErQmz5MpLGYYysCc6YCAPYiK50dT25rp9A/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h43/h001.Dz3gOlAZvxW5zEbugDEl6dO0VgbDZEw_uimu6x8r2dE" target="_blank">CNN’s John Fritze reports</a
>. Still, they must contend with “more than a dozen emergency appeals tied to Trump’s second term, including cases dealing with mass firings, immigration and the president’s efforts to end birthright citizenship,” with more to come even once they break.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>More court reads: </i
></strong
><a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV69rXRyiWqhCzIJbstXnYrx4_LxbcTeoTjhVytxcP0_2VD3Tgeu512tV15-DgzNHUBUnC1daXRE45LG7LkgnFLAELXrfJRale0v2VDvhXT3f7_PZfotaIrODVrjMTC298TQ/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h44/h001._Vhf9Q5V9vcEznMUSmtbC_VYxdOdTpLHJImo4Ri6duM" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>“</i
>Judge tosses Trump order punishing the law firm WilmerHale,”</strong
></a
> by WaPo’s Mark Berman: “U.S. District Judge <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Richard J. Leon</strong
> ruled that Trump’s order was unconstitutional and blocked the government from enforcing it, becoming the third judge this month to side with a law firm that had challenged the president’s orders. … A ruling in the case of the fourth firm, <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Susman Godfrey</strong
>, is still pending, though a judge has temporarily blocked most of Trump’s penalties for that business.”<br></p></td>
                    </tr>

                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">PLAYBOOK METRO SECTION — </strong
>The Metro is launching its tap-to-pay upgrade at a ceremony at Dulles later today. Commuters can now pay for their rides right at the turnstile by tapping their phone, credit card or debit card. <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV686GICqizmddcd-mdebPgQCbuu-zoims82voffTf5d5i63KuTZRj2ywVcF_GbdxtnBVRPJDnrliCs1m9kga-yRKsZqxy1sRtbpGEnoycixyFf8A1VTUC2-uQAVeJWP9kybKNpNnhqHPYNYoq3zdkPMg/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h46/h001.mCj2VcFIVFpJzTJWNsnDjRDdB8IGbD6YvlEJ1_Qf3Nk" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>More from the Washingtonian</i
></strong
></a
></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">FIRST IN PLAYBOOK —</strong
></span> 314 Action has added <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Bri Gillis</strong
> as a campaign adviser for federal and statewide candidates, <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Eden Giagnorio </strong
>as comms director and <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Tara Saye</strong
> as deputy development director.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">TRANSITIONS — Cheyenne Hunt </strong
>is now executive director of Gen-Z for Change. She previously was a big tech accountability advocate at Public Citizen and is an Amy Klobuchar alum. …<strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"> Patrick Lohmeyer</strong
> is now VP of international network programs and partnerships at United Way Worldwide. He most recently was CEO at LINC. …<strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"> Chris Crawford </strong
>will be senior director of civil strategies at Interfaith America. He currently is a policy strategist of free and fair elections at Protect Democracy.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">… Kaylin Dines </strong
>is now chief of staff for Rep. Brittany Pettersen (D-Colo.). She most recently was press secretary and senior adviser for communications at OPM in the Biden administration and is a Yadira Caraveo and Tim Ryan alum. … <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Emma Mears</strong
> is now head of membership development at Ned’s Club. She previously was membership and community manager. And <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Jenna Groesch</strong
> is now head of membership at Ned’s Club. She previously was membership executive at the Club’s New York location.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">ENGAGED — Ted Scheinman</strong
>, senior editor at Smithsonian, and <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Tara Ganapathy</strong
>, counsel in the congressional investigations practice at K&L Gates and a Biden OMB and HHS alum, got engaged on Monday. They met in 2019 and reconnected because their respective interns were friends. He proposed in a park near their house, after hollowing out a portion of the Warren Report and hiding the ring box in there. <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.lWesBdxv006jasBZWiiGkyLH6NelgDGTki4PjY8_g4GGBeY1IF0ModhX5CofmmHW6N28Sr18CNTiTR4qDS0RHf9UI-RFw6T7grExULUacpOqrUjP-LzAOjrNOA4WMwo1tOVvYfBb5ArJCVQThVs5Y7PTLDtEqbkgByVzegAmfeXG1GkRw7oK7g8LH5Cq-6-7GTmmqsSPdVkmiEh8AIci0-Mtb3EjK0eMzLwj-SwHsB0/4gv/5v0kmAdDTnex4uhsjNNczg/h47/h001.CUI59OwJkciqaZSgBleFBCbq0VSTu1bHd-LP9bmRfFc" target="_blank"><strong

    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:20px;line-height:24px;color:#000000;">The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act is positive for homeownership and the middle class. Un nuevo Coffee Break y entradas para el Museo Reina Sofía

 

Despedimos el mes de mayo con nuevas experiencias para ti. Esta semana, consigue tu plaza para asistir al próximo Coffee Break de la temporada, que estará protagonizado por Felipe Lería. Además, hemos abierto un nuevo concurso de entradas para visitar el Museo Reina Sofía. ¿A qué esperas para participar?

encuentros

Felipe Lería, protagonista del próximo Coffee Break de Cinco Días y EL PAÍS

El responsable de Union Bancaire Privée (UBP) Asset Management en Iberia y Latinoamérica es el invitado del próximo Coffee Break, que tendrá lugar el miércoles 4 de junio a las 10:00 a través de la plataforma Zoom. El experto charlará con nuestros suscriptores Premium sobre los últimos bandazos en la guerra comercial desatada por Donald Trump, las perspectivas de los tipos de interés o el potencial que puede tener para el cliente minorista la inversión en activos alternativos a la Bolsa y los bonos. ¡Participa y consigue tu plaza!

 

museos

 

Gana una entrada doble para visitar el Museo Reina Sofía

Por ser lector de EL PAÍS, te ofrecemos la oportunidad de conseguir una invitación doble para visitar el Museo Reina Sofía en la fecha que tú elijas. Las invitaciones son válidas hasta febrero de 2026 y te permitirán acceder a la Colección Permanente del museo (cuya pieza central es Guernica de Pablo Picasso) y a sus exposiciones temporales. ¿A qué esperas para hacerte con las tuyas?

 

MÁS RECOMENDACIONES

Zahara: “La vida no es lo que te estás perdiendo, la vida es donde estás”

La cantautora presentó su nuevo disco ‘Lento ternura’ en un evento exclusivo para suscriptores de EL PAÍS. Disfruta de los mejores momentos en este vídeo.

 

Jacobo Bergareche: “La muerte, la paternidad, la amistad y el amor son las únicas cosas importantes. El resto son modas”

El autor ha protagonizado el Club de lectura de abril de EL PAÍS para charlar sobre ‘Los días perfectos’. Ya puedes ver el encuentro íntegro aquí.

17.subject: Wednesday Briefing: Chaos at a Gaza aid site
17.body:
Plus, climbing Mount Everest with a performance enhancer.
View in browser|nytimes.com
May 28, 2025

By Justin Porter

Good morning. We’re covering the chaotic opening of a new aid center in Gaza and King Charles’s throne speech in Canada.

Plus, climbing Mount Everest with a performance enhancer.

Palestinians carrying aid packages delivered in Rafah, southern Gaza, yesterday. Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

Crowds overran a new aid distribution site in Gaza

Chaos broke out at a new aid center in the Gaza Strip yesterday, the first full day that humanitarian assistance was distributed through a contentious effort conceived by Israelis.

Footage verified by The Times showed large crowds, including women and young children, running toward the center of the site where boxes of aid had been piled up earlier in the day. In one video, a crowd could be seen running away as several short bursts of gunfire were heard in the distance. Israel’s blockade of aid since March has left Palestinians desperate for supplies.

The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, the organization behind the effort, said that the site was so overwhelmed that the foundation’s team retreated “to allow a small number of Gazans to take aid safely and dissipate.”

Cease-fire: Mediators are seeking to urgently broker a deal in Gaza, but Israel, the U.S. and Hamas have sent conflicting messages about progress in truce talks.

West Bank: Israeli soldiers killed Amer Rabee, a 14-year-old Palestinian American, branding him a terrorist. His killing has added to accusations that the Israeli military uses excessive force and operates with impunity.

Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany, left, and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv this month. Genya Savilov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

Germany’s leader steps forward as a key backer of Ukraine

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine today will pay his first visit to Germany since Chancellor Friedrich Merz took office. With the future of Washington’s commitment to Kyiv in doubt, Merz has become a leading figure in the European alliance supporting Ukraine.

A major topic of conversation is likely to be military aid and, specifically, the Taurus cruise missile, a system jointly developed by Germany and Sweden. The previous government refused to provide the Taurus, a stance Merz criticized. But since taking office, Merz has been vague about whether he will send the missile to Ukraine.

A stronger army: Merz has made military spending a priority, taking out huge loans to rebuild an aging military. He has vowed to make Germany’s army the strongest conventional military force in Europe and to take on more of a leadership role in NATO.

Other developments about Ukraine:

  • Russia is building power lines in occupied southeastern Ukraine to link its own grid to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, according to a Greenpeace report.
  • A small but vocal group of Republicans in Congress is urging sweeping new sanctions against Russia, diverging sharply from President Trump’s conciliatory stance.
Pool photo by Chris Jackson

King Charles delivered a subtle rebuke to Trump

In a speech formally opening the new session of Canada’s Parliament, King Charles painted a grim picture of the state of the world and suggested the situation was caused by Trump’s economic policies. “We must be cleareyed,” Charles said in Ottawa. “The world is a more dangerous and uncertain place than at any point since the Second World War.”

The visit by the king, who is Canada’s head of state, was seen as a rebuke to Trump’s claims that Canada should become the 51st U.S. state. Prime Minister Mark Carney suggested that he had taken the unusual step of having the monarch open Parliament to emphasize Canada’s distinct heritage from the U.S. Here’s what else to know about the king’s visit.

MORE TOP NEWS

Stephane Mahe/Reuters
  • France: A verdict will be handed down today in the trial of a doctor accused of abusing 299 former patients in the biggest pedophilia case in French history.
  • Trump: A federal judge struck down President Trump’s attempt to punish an elite law firm associated with his political opposition.
  • U.K.: Aiming to stop the spread of rumors, the police in Liverpool quickly announced that a driver who rammed his vehicle into a crowd on Monday was a white British man. Here’s how the parade car crash, which injured 65 people, unfolded.
  • Immigration: The U.S. paused interviews abroad for student and visiting scholar visas while it overhauls its system for scrutinizing applicants’ social media.
  • Space: SpaceX’s Starship spun out of control in space before breaking apart during its ninth test flight.
  • Africa: Joseph Kabila, the former president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, has returned to his country, arriving in rebel-controlled Goma.
  • Crime: A third person accused of kidnapping a man and torturing him for nearly three weeks in a luxury Manhattan townhouse to steal his Bitcoin fortune surrendered to the police.
  • North Korea: Satellite images and video show how last week’s launch of a new 5,000-ton destroyer turned into an embarrassing failure.

Tariffs and Business

  • China: An all-out trade war with the U.S. could result in huge job losses.
  • Japan: The cabinet approved a $6.3 billion spending package to support businesses and households adversely affected by the tariffs.
  • Ships: A U.S. plan to revive American shipbuilding faces obstacles: U.S. ships cost five times as much to make as Asian ones.

SPORTS NEWS

Franck Fife/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
  • Tennis: On Day 3 of the French Open, Novak Djokovic swung into action, as did Coco Gauff. We have live updates.
  • Soccer: We look back at the best, worst and most unusual moments of the 2024-25 English Premier League season.
  • Golf: Why the U.S. Women’s Open comes at a brilliant time for the sport.

MORNING READ

Sandro Gromen/Associated Press

Climbing Mount Everest usually takes weeks, but four men traveled from London to the summit and back in less than seven days with a secret weapon: xenon gas. Inhalation of the gas is thought to improve oxygen levels.

Their feat has roiled the world of mountaineering and prompted an investigation by the government of Nepal. Read more.

CONVERSATION STARTERS

Patrick Junker for The New York Times
  • Darkness lingers: A German village grapples with a brutal past: It was originally built as a community for the Nazi elite.
  • Jessica McCormack: The jeweler behind Zendaya’s very large engagement ring injects cool-girl energy into pieces for stars.
  • What’s on tap: A writer was wary of tap water. But, after some exploration, she realized “it connects you to the ecosystem around you.”
  • Spoiled views: Residents of a medieval fortress town in Greece are feuding over a plan to build a cable car to the peak, where a beautiful 12th-century church sits.

ARTS AND IDEAS

Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times

A sci-fi writer on China’s rise and his own decline

To read Han Song can feel like exploring recent history. In 2000, he wrote a novel depicting the collapse of the World Trade Center. In 2016, he imagined the world transformed into a giant hospital. Now, his thoughts have turned inward.

On social media, Han has described, in unsparing detail, the onset of his dementia and other ailments. But if human frailty is a common theme in his writing, so is something slightly more optimistic: the value of writing about it. Read our profile of Han.

We hope you’ve enjoyed this newsletter, which is made possible through subscriber support. Subscribe to The New York Times.

RECOMMENDATIONS

Linda Xiao for The New York Times

Cook: Fresh mint and orange zest make this simple salmon recipe come to life.

Listen: “More” is the Britpop group Pulp’s first album since 2001.

Read: “Peace Is a Shy Thing” provides an exhaustive biography of Tim O’Brien, one of the foremost chroniclers of the Vietnam War.

Travel: Land snorkeling? Townsizing? Explore the lingo of travel trends.

Soothe: Different classes of pain relievers work in different ways. Here’s how to figure out which one is effective for you.

Play the Spelling Bee. And here are today’s Mini Crossword and Wordle. You can find all our puzzles here.

That’s it for today’s briefing. See you tomorrow. — Justin

We welcome your feedback. Send us your suggestions at briefing@nytimes.com.

¡Queremos verte en la Feria del Libro de Madrid!

 

Como cada miércoles, traemos a tu bandeja de entrada experiencias culturales únicas. Esta semana, consigue tus entradas para disfrutar de la ópera El barbero de Sevilla desde la comodidad de las butacas de Cine Yelmo. Además, tenemos reservada una sorpresa para el final...¡Sigue leyendo!

 

 

cine yelmo

 

Antetítulo

Disfruta de El barbero de Sevilla en Cine Yelmo

El barbero de Sevilla, la efervescente y alocada comedia de Giacomo Rossini, será la encargada de poner el broche de oro el próximo 31 de mayo a la temporada MET Ópera 24/25 en Cine Yelmo. Esta obra, tan popular como disfrutable, se podrá ver en vivo y en directo desde Nueva York gracias a +Que Cine, la ventana de contenidos alternativos de Cine Yelmo. Participa y consigue una entrada doble para ver esta ópera en tu Cine Yelmo más cercano.

 

feria del libro de madrid

 

¿Quieres estar presente en la Feria del Libro de Madrid?

Queremos que nuestros lectores de toda España estén presentes en la Feria del Libro de Madrid, que celebrará su 84º edición del 30 de mayo al 15 de junio en el Parque del Retiro. ¿Y qué mejor manera de hacerlo que desde la portada gigante que EL PAÍS llevará a la feria? La ilustradora Paula Bressel pintará en ella las caricaturas de 12 lectores a partir de fotos que nos envíen. ¿Quieres ser uno de ellos? Envíanos tu foto para que Paula la convierta en caricatura. ¡Tienes hasta el próximo 26 de mayo!

21.body:
It looks like your email client might not support HTML formatted email. Try opening this email in another email client. Or, open the following link to view this email in a browser: https://e.emailalerts.cnn.com/click? ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We respect your privacy, if this e-mail has been sent to you by error or you no longer wish to receive email, open the following link in a browser to unsubscribe: https://e.emailalerts.cnn.com/click?
Trump pardons reality show couple convicted of bank fraud and tax crimes

 

News Alert: Trump pardons reality show couple convicted of bank fraud and tax crimes

President Donald Trump has signed full pardons for imprisoned reality show couple Todd and Julie Chrisley, who were sentenced to lengthy prison terms in 2022 for a conspiracy to defraud banks out of more than $30 million, according to a White House official.

In addition to the bank fraud convictions, they were also found guilty of several tax crimes, including attempting to defraud the Internal Revenue Service.

In a post on X, Trump’s adviser Margo Martin posted a video of Trump phoning Savannah Chrisley, the couple’s daughter, informing her of the plans for pardons.
