   <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;background-color:#FFFFFF;">
    <p style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:12px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:10px;color:#000000;">A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:</p>
    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height:15px;"><a href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKCJCpfzLXKLU6KDtDs6qCfYrBryUczlVs2Z-c50x2vJlt3irJJ3AKGfJ7OuLnzZlpg86awhCqcjXaiKl0hlI1gSywGXc0spzF9ySKsf2p5ucXRpKtoC5uWmJAwOLc8ilrSnWZZGqF9QhBAwwKLP80po/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h43/h001.BTR8Wjf7PaMd91AKA6MBJ1U3PNRhEmq4NnJAgG3sLRE" target="_blank"><img src="https://www.politico.com/dims4/default/08dd711/2147483647/resize/1000x/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fstatic.politico.com%2F6f%2F50%2F2d442baa446789b6ec1613b9f548%2Fttsat500x500.jpg" title="Advertisement Image" alt="Advertisement Image" border="0" width="500" style="width:100%;max-width:500px;"></a> <img src="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/ad/N7384.146504POLITICO0/B33683778.421820636;sz=1x1;ord=[timestamp]" border="0" a></p>
    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:20px;line-height:24px;color:#000000;">The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act is positive for homeownership and the middle class. <a href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKCJCpfzLXKLU6KDtDs6qCfYrBryUczlVs2Z-c50x2vJlBChcHA4eYgeN8KOLcGihggYYUlM46LL2KI06xCZQGqaDGOAKwiBeKAchDrnMVOaSGlrEy9CzpZRw4W888rNh-yILj0WAlgG7-IIuVPCMum4/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h44/h001.2UvKQs4s_yL1TbZ5zytyT2fEncCmgnEgcr8i8dhJrWk" target="_blank" style="text-decoration:underline;color:#007BC7;">Learn more.</a></p></td>

                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><span style="color:#b70000;font-weight:bold;font-family:sans-serif;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">BEST OF THE REST</strong
></span></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">IMMIGRATION FILES: </strong
>Since the start of the year, more than <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">10,000 </strong
>would-be immigrants (almost all Venezuelans) have <i
>reversed course</i
> and gotten boats from Panama to Colombia, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV64bdYmMUM90y4Dz49LTdagvtxodq--eHbFbH315sDa7pXnzpAq4xoTxoJaA5M6fL3dhnZKu1LizwSjwfWHFMTaueXYlWGk_fPxGI87-ZIVFf/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h45/h001.DjJA3rFEu0cZRMhBOzooB7yeTmta0I3YtOcd6NZergg" target="_blank">NYT’s Annie Correal reports</a
> (from on board one such vessel). Their willingness to undertake a potentially life-threatening journey — for the second time — highlights just how far Trump has transformed the border debate in a few short months.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">THE DEPORTATION DOLLAR:</strong
> <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV60GpfVie-RJAMk8zWuUuez3Ivofya76YIwjkGgzpCszw-1SwB2CaGQCTIQbHB0wnNCtj8YgRrLDEpgKYh4IJbJW046HI73Q-NdsdxLrJUj5X/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h46/h001.ylKmuCwfbYgqT8A1krCbJIaCjG71l1Z6zdyhcRETJY4" target="_blank">WSJ’s Elizabeth Findell and colleagues have an illuminating breakdown</a
> of how many different companies profit from just one person’s deportation. And <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKP6B7k0A8Lo57NWsGrvI97L73NXNSQ0_2An0SCXHm4oPWC9ZGmYDzPiR_j2KU75pfVdjfZY1c9xbaosJilRArtaj2MP6H3nd4aOVHCNRspBmUznb8XlqO-xPx0Z3lgg-ZA/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h47/h001.gAJivwpT1IhVUujbgn0d3gilC1se-K8d9wL3ETdueZg" target="_blank">AP’s Joshua Goodman dives into</a
> the complicated South Florida politics of the growing crackdown on Cuban immigrants.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">SCHOOL TIES: </strong
>Trump keeps escalating his fight against Harvard. His latest <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.tZBh-UKX-I3yMqqHCXLb8yfOydSt7swN-GhaAPY3eIN9MnYXvDYGv-VD-Gll-KXMvIhha-AfYOSjs_MOLCQC7VIe6ZQoxMqX_M43ISNKNuU/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h48/h001.h6mPOb-w9au1Z3JE-V-ZDCSRGEYwGtXGK_VZBwzbUpw" target="_blank">Truth Social salvo</a
> — one of several fired at the Ivy League uni over the holiday weekend — saw the president floating the idea of redirecting $3 billion in frozen federal grants to trade schools. It’s not yet clear how serious the idea is, or how he’d accomplish it. But we’re bound to hear more soon enough.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">INCOMING: </strong
>FBI Deputy Director <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Dan Bongino </strong
>announced the bureau is reopening or ramping up three investigations into topics that have long been hot on the right: the 2021 pipe bombs planted near the DNC and RNC; POLITICO’s 2022 mega-scoop disclosing the Supreme Court draft decision overturning <i
>Roe v. Wade</i
>; and the bag of cocaine discovered at the White House in 2023. <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV62W888RNZ4cQxj3VSJcbw_G28TkLhVkqQmNvmlt5Oc_3fDIlzRuD1JCfG3RbI2ZihmrnT7UuL7jpPMEj-B_ALf0/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h49/h001.xe6EZHss2GSMZiOjd7bRPUWWjAtfVlC8dj8Kc-3J2VM" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>More from CBS</i
></strong
></a
><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
> </i
></strong
></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">ANOTHER INSTITUTION UNDER ATTACK: </strong
><a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV65ZWHEH5gWGSDKLrcKzwr3-3nc9BABKSkMt8osi9MRaa5d3_CLXhGH1Y80F1QEXB0Ru6N52VwMewcVzXnzapH7BWEgMMKeK_RBg7aVWkI2UGE6f78yxjO7EDocFMAgYiAMl30CKzuOCFFxXsPY6r5ug3EcoJ0t8ArphKxNN_lEhnRiDUUYCHZgBJ9IwRMjMDCQd0ez6m2iPkVdtIf0WNLRC8Dj1C7nHTLU-RY3emwEx9/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h50/h001.8G9HrNI9UX8ASxyd0pGWLvhNJty_E9rITelAnSup9Og" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">“GOP declares war on GAO,”</strong
></a
> by POLITICO’s Jennifer Scholtes and colleagues: “The independent Government Accountability Office has served Congress as the nation’s chief investigator of wrongdoing at federal agencies for more than a century. Now it’s under assault. The typically uncontroversial, under-the-radar agency is fighting to retain power against attempts by Republicans in the Trump administration and on Capitol Hill to undercut its legal conclusions and independence — an onslaught that has been fast and furious.”</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">ALL THAT GLITTERS: </strong
>With the super-rich having amassed a greater share of America’s wealth than during the Gilded Age, <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV67uHtca8Q1l9qwJW2jARkJJlN4cHusRfgGAT96DGT93sHMV2eq1xQj4LyDBN1gy4wJHZZznWKj2QvoEGvva0If02sLYrOiNFHgZPYBbvTPSW/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h51/h001.DalwsklqvxrOMUV9LrQ7E9SC9wZTFGciffAbSIU__bI" target="_blank">The New Yorker’s Evan Osnos takes a scalpel</a
> to concerns about oligarchy and corruption under Trump. The article includes this startling claim, which takes pay-to-play to a whole new level: People can secure individual conversations with Trump by donating <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">$5 million </strong
>to his super PAC MAGA Inc.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">BUT BUT BUT:</strong
> Some of the crypto billionaires who bought a ton of Trump memecoins to bag a seat at last week’s controversial dinner at Trump’s golf club were not exactly impressed with what they got. Some said they found Trump’s speech “inspiring,” <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV6wayDWFDU_dq_Z5Ef5dHIwxexHjzyND6ROH3z8BXI7wDgs7fxO0eQPperLqJ9kUAc81bOLeHt0BbM6uuwo5inih7AszHkkYxQdLwIPbcBE1k8rzjMRj8WSZAf_Wh_eIMMg/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h52/h001.ZlP-vH6zbkewb2zKG1fcj9k-ddXszXia5OUnSKkC0bQ" target="_blank">per this glorious color write-up in Wired</a
>, but others complained about the brevity of his speech, the lack of direct access to Trump and even the quality of the meal.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">SPEAKING OF CRYPTO: </strong
><a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV63aQSPEmkzNqK5Qcwg5UhIHzUkRbik2Um1SKXIgY77yoq0oHYHsKZwgAbaDNOeHTLIxVAnxFtqNp9R5yv4jbEmM/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h53/h001.iVeGuNbxFzEX6czyZ1FmWPyQ2M2qvjXjV9R8zox4UvI" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">“Trump media group plans to raise $3bn to spend on cryptocurrencies,”</strong
></a
> by FT’s Antoine Gara and colleagues: “Trump Media & Technology Group, which is behind the Truth Social app and controlled by the president’s family, aims to raise $2bn in fresh equity and another $1bn via a convertible bond … TMTG’s capital raising could be announced ahead of a big meeting of crypto investors and advocates in Las Vegas this week.”<br></p></td>
                    </tr>
                
                    <tr>
                        
</tr><tr>

                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding-bottom:10px; min-width:100%; width:100%;">
    <table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" role="presentation" style="background-color:#121522; min-width:100%;">

            <td width="32" valign="middle" style="vertical-align:top;font-size:0;text-align:right;padding-top:10px;"><img src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/origin-static.politico.com/hosted/icon-red-circle%402x.png" title="" alt="" width="12" style="max-width:12px;margin-top:1px;"></td>
            <td style="text-align:left;font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:12px;color:#FFFFFF;text-transform:uppercase;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:2px;padding-top:10px;padding-bottom:10px;padding-left:10px;margin:0;" valign="middle">TALK OF THE TOWN</td>

                    <tr>
                        <td style="padding:0 20px 0 20px;text-align:left;font-family:Georgia,serif;font-size:16px;color:#000000;"><p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">IN MEMORIAM — </strong
><a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV64bdYmMUM90y4Dz49LTdagtBlZppAy_5PavKDSIicq9dta0yLVGvreLz-KtBymui_xyqz05IdpyzocAWxHzq79Q/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h55/h001.RZtw5vUwBUqOyv41YhzDAml5iWY6wfP5josVZqQMHio" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">“Charles B. Rangel, Longtime Harlem Congressman, Dies at 94,”</strong
></a
> by NYT’s Sam Roberts: He “became the first Black chairman of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee, only to relinquish that position when he was censured for an ethics violation … A mainstay of Harlem’s Democratic old guard, Mr. Rangel was first elected to Congress in 1970 … Mr. Rangel retired in 2016 after winning a 23rd term despite the ethics allegation — making him the ninth-longest continuously serving member of the House in American history. In 2000, he was instrumental in persuading Hillary Clinton to enter electoral politics.”</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">SCENE SETTER — </strong
><a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.6g0Zd3AyneOViJYBXgbV64bdYmMUM90y4Dz49LTdagsAOho4MkjZlqaobboGkfUTxf4opxWGmOkmlBoYT2DaGPAQ_wIWyWibjIH6E9MxW_cYTMl9rzGmAtJA8DOG1UGI/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h56/h001.1TJPJdO9w8385-RyURAhXL-7kDyNlbWQCi_VrKrbG74" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">“Members Only: A New Trump Club, Ned’s Club and the Enduring Old Guard,”</strong
></a
> by NYT’s Elisabeth Bumiller: “In a 2025 Washington firebombed by political and ideological differences, [Executive Branch, Ned’s Club, Metropolitan Club and Cosmos Club] are growing, have wait lists or both. While they have varied levels of snobbery and exclusivity, Executive Branch is an outlier because of the price [up to $500,000] of its access to the White House and its enrichment of the Trump family. But all four clubs reflect the sorting of the city’s establishment into separate corners at a turbulent time.”</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">TRANSITIONS — Sarah Flaim</strong
> is now head of congressional affairs at Forterra. She most recently was a managing director at DCI Group, and is a Hill alum. … <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">Jared Henderson</strong
> is now a director of government affairs at Growth Energy. He previously was senior policy adviser for Sen. Ben Ray Luján (D-N.M.).</p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">WEEKEND WEDDINGS — Andy Flick, </strong
>a principal at Cornerstone Government Affairs and a Kamala Harris alum, and <strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">David Ochsman, </strong
>a VP at Compass, got married in a small ceremony Friday in Montgomery County, Maryland. They met in D.C. 14 years ago at a cocktail party. <a
 href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.lWesBdxv006jasBZWiiGkyLH6NelgDGTki4PjY8_g4GxHR98shHvgChhiyW8Z5UVAFioCqsM01slEyIOOVVudRZHqFoxiBIuAT4GW46wHnNtbFLgJOLPyYZrzAzDFfBtjpKQ-AMiiQDhlbm9NyVCEaRaVio4L8o_X2XS5_WJ4JFWa9bFGGNg5RqXTOppkbKr6GRC1o55rn9Zjjwld27WPewlMfiQE6D3pSCZNrxYBiMfCuiEakVOD24bKkxaiy8k/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h57/h001.kzqxa9hmtR5tsYgCOo0RSIJIY7fhOr-j7rcJgTs6NUQ" target="_blank"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;"><i
>Pic</i
></strong
></a
></p>
<p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:24px;line-height:24px;"><strong
 style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-weight:bold;">— Melissa Byars</strong

> (R-S.C.) officiated. The couple met in law school at the University of South Carolina. <a

></strong

    <p style="font-family:Helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:12px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:10px;color:#000000;">A message from The National Association of REALTORS®:</p>
    <p style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:20px;line-height:24px;color:#000000;">The House-passed One Big Beautiful Bill Act is positive for homeownership and the middle class. A recent survey commissioned by the National Association of REALTORS® shows strong, bipartisan voter support for key provisions in the bill that make housing more affordable. From extending lower tax rates and SALT relief to incentives for small businesses and community investment, this bill delivers real benefits that will strengthen the American Dream and help build resilient communities. However, there is still more bipartisan work to be done to bring down the cost of housing. <a href="https://url4027.email.politico.com/ss/c/u001.dgGKIUEMNqic94f5rSpPKCJCpfzLXKLU6KDtDs6qCfYrBryUczlVs2Z-c50x2vJl--m3u93jM53msDUY8DYfbtxLx0P-1bfvf4KqFUMhOYglpJ4jrCX9UFUdYzbs1rhrspGqZI6vJcwPcFDYN-FJjKjNu1ExEALj2xRq9k-cL9o/4gu/a32GNxkdSBGfBGYWxnWMUg/h61/h001.3iK-gr859asMUoE_1x5Mrtxceoavp9_LJv-_pNuF3yU" target="_blank" style="text-decoration:underline;color:#007BC7;">Learn more.</a></p></td>

36.subject: Chaos erupts at US-backed aid site in Gaza
36.body:
Subject Line: Chaos erupts at US-backed aid site in Gaza Preheader: Gaza ... Immigration ... DOGE ... Harvard ... SpaceX ... It looks like your email client might not support HTML formatted email. Try opening this email in another email client. Or, open the following link to view this email in a browser: https://e.newsletters.cnn.com/click? ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We respect your privacy, if this e-mail has been sent to you by error or you no longer wish to receive email, open the following link in a browser to unsubscribe: https://e.newsletters.cnn.com/click?
Gaza ... Immigration ... DOGE ... Harvard ... SpaceX ...

Wednesday, May 28, 2025

View in browser
 

By Jade Walker

Remember when Southwest Airlines’ policy was “bags fly free?” Those days are now over. On flights booked today and going forward, the carrier will charge travelers $35 for checking one bag, $45 for a second and $150 for a third checked bag. Overweight luggage will require paying up to $200 in fees. 

 

Here's what else you need to know to get up to speed and on with your day.

Palestinians seeking aid rush over a dirt berm that surrounds a distribution site in Rafah. Reuters

1

 

Gaza

It’s been 600 days since Hamas launched a surprise attack on Israel, killing more than 1,200 people and kidnapping 250 others. Since then, the militant group has released some of the hostages, but continued to fire rockets at Israel. Israel has responded by negotiating for the release of hostages, bombing much of Gaza and killing more than 53,000 people. In recent months, Israel has also halted access to humanitarian aid, which has pushed the enclave’s population of more than 2 million Palestinians towards famine. Although access to aid resumed this week, chaos broke out at a distribution site in southern Gaza on Tuesday as thousands of desperate Palestinians arrived to receive food from a controversial new US and Israel-backed aid distribution program. Jake Wood, the head of the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, resigned on Sunday, saying, “it is not possible to implement this plan while also strictly adhering to the humanitarian principles of humanity, neutrality, impartiality, and independence, which I will not abandon.”

2

 

Immigration

President Donald Trump asked the Supreme Court on Tuesday to make it easier for his administration to deport people to countries where they don’t hold citizenship. The policy, which was adopted soon after Trump returned to office, allowed the Department of Homeland Security to send immigrants to nations other than their home country without first notifying them or giving them a chance to claim a risk of persecution, torture or death in that third-party country. When a group of immigrants facing deportation to war-torn South Sudan sued, a federal judge blocked the US from deporting them unless they received written notice and had the chance to demonstrate a credible fear of persecution or torture there. The judge later said the administration violated his court order when it attempted to send several detainees of various nationalities to South Sudan.

3

 

DOGE

A federal judge ruled in the Trump administration’s favor on Tuesday, saying the Department of Government Efficiency can access sensitive Treasury Department systems that contain private information about millions of Americans. A coalition of 19 states filed the lawsuit earlier this year to block DOGE from accessing the payment systems. In her latest ruling, US District Judge Jeannette Vargas said she would allow the Elon Musk-backed team at Treasury to access systems that control trillions of dollars of payments because the administration had created a process to train the DOGE staffers and prevent improper disclosures of private data. Earlier this year, DOGE staffers attempted to use the Treasury payment systems to shut down payments for programs they didn’t believe should be funded.

4

 

Harvard

In its latest salvo against Harvard University, the White House has directed federal agencies to cancel all remaining contracts with the Ivy League school, two senior Trump administration officials said. Such a move would cost the university about $100 million. That's on top of the $2.65 billion already cut from Harvard after the administration demanded the school change its hiring and admission requirements, eliminate diversity, equity and inclusion programs and alter rules for on-campus protests. The school resisted those orders and filed a lawsuit claiming the government’s actions violate the First Amendment. Last week, the administration tried to halt Harvard’s ability to enroll foreign students, but a federal judge put that on hold. And on Tuesday, the State Department instructed US embassies and consulates around the world to pause new student visa appointments. 

 

Paid Partner Content

Babbel's Memorial Day sale

Start speaking a new language by summer with Babbel. All you need is 10 minutes a day. Get 65% off a subscription during their biggest sale of the year!

 

Experts urge Americans to access home equity before it's too late

Dreaming of a new kitchen or upgraded bathroom? Tap into your home equity - with average loans over $94K, you could fund your reno and have cash left over. Get quotes in minutes.

 

Seven ways to make money by doing (almost) nothing

There’s nothing to be ashamed of if you're living paycheck to paycheck or struggling to make ends meet. Thankfully, there are ways that you can make and save some money right now if you are struggling financially.

5

 

SpaceX

While conducting the ninth uncrewed test flight of its Starship megarocket, SpaceX lost control of the spacecraft, which likely disintegrated over the Indian Ocean. The company was attempting to reuse a Super Heavy rocket booster that was previously flown and recaptured after a launch in January. The company wants to recover, refurbish and reuse as much of a rocket as possible to save money on future missions. Although Starship made it farther into its flight path during Flight 9 than in previous tests, it was not able to accomplish key objectives, such as deploying the test satellites it was carrying or reigniting engines upon reentry. The last two test missions — Flight 7 in January and Flight 8 in March — ended in explosive failures.

 

breakfast browse

 

People are talking about these. Read up. Join in.

Mary Lou Retton arrested
Police in her West Virginia hometown took the 57-year-old gymnastics icon into custody earlier this month on suspicion of driving under the influence. 

 

Harry Potter TV show casts its stars
HBO has finally found a trio of young actors to play Harry Potter, Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley in its upcoming series about the magical world of witchcraft and wizardry. (HBO, like CNN, is owned by Warner Bros. Discovery.)

 

CosMc’s to close
McDonald’s is planning to shutter all five of its beverage-focused spinoff locations in June. However, some of the customizable drinks will stick around.

There’s a fungus among us
As the climate crisis intensifies, researchers say Aspergillus, a common group of infection-causing fungi, will spread to new regions of the planet.

 

Stop stealing the stones, folks
A city in Belgium is asking tourists not to take a piece of its UNESCO-recognized medieval streets home with them. 

 
 
 

Sponsor Content by LendingTree

How to get cash from your home without refinancing

If you’re a homeowner, here’s a secret hack a lot of people don’t know about: your home equity! You could borrow over $94k and use it for just about anything – a home renovation, paying off credit card debt – whatever you want! 

 

in memoriam

 

Rock guitarist/producer Rick Derringer dies
During his six-decade music career, Derringer released the hit singles “Hang On Sloopy” with his band The McCoys, and “Rock and Roll, Hoochie Koo” from his solo album “All American Boy.” He also worked with numerous artists — including Ringo Starr, Steely Dan, B.B. King and Barbra Streisand — and produced “Weird Al” Yankovic’s first six albums.

100

 

That’s how many hours climate and weather scientists plan to livestream presentations to protest the Trump administration’s cuts to NOAA, NASA and the Department of Energy, as well as research funding to academia. The livestream marathon, which is billed as nonpartisan, begins today at 1 p.m. ET. 

quotable

 

“I was disappointed to see the massive spending bill, frankly, which increases the budget deficit, not just decreases it, and undermines the work that the DOGE team is doing. I think a bill can be big or it can be beautiful, but I don’t know if it can be both.”

 

— Elon Musk on President Trump’s sweeping tax and spending cuts package. 

 

pick of the day

 

Follow the data. Follow the experts. Follow the facts.

Get unlimited access to world-renowned, fact-based journalism for less than $1/week. The truth has never been more essential.

Does not include live TV

Subscribe to CNN

and finally...

 
 

Rowing for William
Joe Jackson’s 6-year-old son William suffers from Duchenne muscular dystrophy. There is a potential treatment available, but it costs $2.2 million. So, Jackson set out to raise those funds by rowing nonstop for 31 hours.

We want to hear from you. Questions, ideas or feedback?

Let us know

37.subject: Early Brief: The varied issues facing American manufacturing
37.body:
Early Brief from The Washington Post

In today’s edition … King Charles III steps into the...

‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

PUBLISHED BY   <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/3f88b0d/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/4/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>   READ ONLINE <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/camp-rw/?trackId=596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d&s=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&linknum=5&linktot=56>

Early Brief <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/3f88b0d/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/6/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>

 

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=1069949&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=default>

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=1069949&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=default>

Are you still interested in this newsletter?

Since you haven't read in a while, we'll pause sending it to you. Let us know if you still would like to keep receiving it.

Yes, keep this newsletter <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/40bd174/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/9/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>

 

Matthew Choi and Dan Merica">       By Matthew Choi <mailto:matthew.choi@washpost.com> and Dan Merica <mailto:Dan.Merica@washpost.com>

<https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a19/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/12/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>
Listen to this briefing <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a19/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/13/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>

Good morning, Early Birds. One of us is enjoying the NBA playoffs, foul artists <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a1a/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/14/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> and all. Send tips to earlytips@washpost.com <mailto:earlytips@washpost.com>. Thanks for waking up with us.

In today’s edition … King Charles III goes to the mat for Canada … Senate Democrats preview their Medicaid messaging … Sen. Tuberville looks for an exit … but first …
The varied issues facing American manufacturing

Donald Trump speaks during a campaign event at the Precision Components Group building in York, Pennsylvania, last year. (Tom Brenner/For The Washington Post)

President Donald Trump is pressing to invigorate manufacturing in the United States.

He said Sunday that his trade policy is aimed at making “big things” in the U.S. again, not just T-shirts and sneakers. “We are looking to do chips and computers and lots of other things, and tanks and ships,” Trump said. To that end, last month, Trump signed an executive order <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1b/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/16/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> aimed at encouraging Americans to go into high-skilled trade jobs.

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=default>

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=default>

According to experts and recent examinations of the American labor market, that may not be enough.

There are major issues facing American manufacturing, and yes, those issues include cheaper labor abroad and trade barriers in other countries, two problems Trump is trying to address through tariffs.

But his trade policy largely ignores key domestic issues: Widespread job openings that companies are struggling to fill and an aging workforce with millions set to retire over the next decade. The declining size of the American workforce is further exacerbated by the president’s efforts to decrease immigration, particularly in skilled-labor professions.

“This gets into an immigration debate. … We’ll have students from Asia come in to study, but they can’t stay. And so we educate them at taxpayer expense, and then they go back to our competition,” Rep. Michael McCaul (R-Texas) recently told us at a Washington Post Live event on manufacturing. “I had this bill several years ago. If you get a PhD in high-skilled engineering, you get a green card. … I’m not sure how others in the administration may view that now.”

There were about 450,000 open manufacturing jobs in March, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1c/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/19/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>, positions that companies are struggling to fill. And a study last year <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1d/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/20/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> by the Manufacturing Institute — a nonprofit workforce development and education affiliate of the National Association of Manufacturers — and Deloitte found that recruiting and retaining workers was the most pressing issue for top manufacturing companies.

“The U.S. manufacturing industry could see a net need for as many as 3.8 million jobs between 2024 and 2033 as significant investment continues to drive growth,” read the report <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1d/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/21/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>. “Without significant changes, more than 5 in 10 or 1.9 million of these jobs could go unfilled if workforce challenges are not addressed through 2033.”

Central to that problem is age. The average age of a manufacturing worker is 44.3 <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1e/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/22/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> years, older than the 42-year-old average age of all workers in America, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Only 8 percent of manufacturing workers are under 25 years old. The Census Bureau also found in 2020 that “nearly one-fourth of the manufacturing workforce is age 55 or older.” And surveys show that few younger Americans are interested in factory work <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1f/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/23/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>.

Advertisement

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=689175&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>

 

To Carolyn Lee, president of the Manufacturing Institute, this is an issue of perception vs. reality.

“The age of the manufacturing workforce has long been a challenge for us,” Lee said. “People don’t understand what manufacturing is all about today. They have this image of something they have seen on television or in the movies. So there is this disconnect between understanding the reality of the sector and what the potential of those jobs are and what people believe them to be. Perception is one of our biggest gaps.”

This issue is a political football in nearly every presidential campaign. As states such as Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania have grown in political relevance, so too has the issue of manufacturing, with presidential candidates often sparring over who will be better for the trades.

A “manufacturing renaissance” was the centerpiece of Trump’s economic policy during his 2024 run. “You will see a mass exodus of manufacturing from China to Pennsylvania, from Korea to North Carolina, from Germany to right here in Georgia,” Trump told an audience <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a20/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/25/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> in that state months before the election.

But analysts at Wells Fargo <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a21/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/26/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> recently found that “a meaningful increase in factory jobs does not appear likely in the foreseeable future,” because just to bring the industry back to its high point of around 1980, it will cost “at a minimum $2.9 trillion in net new capital investment.”

“There is no one lever that is going to fix all the things that ails us when it comes to workforce development,” Lee said. “Most people think of manufacturing that you are standing on an assembly line and doing a single manual function and that is 40 years of your career. And that is far from the truth. That is why we need to tell the story of manufacturing jobs.”
On the campaign trail
Senate Democrats are looking to make the sweeping spending bill passed by the House a political cudgel, launching a digital ad campaign <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a22/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/27/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> today that ties Senate Republicans to the House bill that would cut Medicaid spending and lock in tax cuts for higher earners.

Advertisement

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=689179&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>

 

The 60-second digital spot — titled “Devastating” — will run on Meta platforms and a range of digital TV channels. It shows a simple Google search asking, “What’s happening with the Republican budget,” followed by news reports on what the bill’s Medicaid cuts would mean for states and how taxes would go down for top earners. “The Republican budget is wrong for American families,” a text block reads at the end of the spot.

The ad highlights how the months-long work by the House will probably become a central point of Democratic messaging in the 2026 midterms, whether or not the Senate changes the bill in the coming weeks.

“Under the leadership of Senate Republicans, millions of people are at risk of losing their health insurance — and voters will hold them accountable for it at the ballot box in 2026,” committee spokeswoman Maeve Coyle said.

In other campaign news: Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-Alabama) is officially running for governor after weeks of anticipation. He had been hinting at a run but made it official during an interview on Fox News yesterday.

“I’m a football coach. I’m a leader. I’m a builder. I’m a recruiter, and we’re going to grow Alabama,” Tuberville said. “We’re going to bring manufacturing to this state. We’re going to stop this illegal immigration.”

Tuberville is a first-term senator who was elected in 2020 after a career coaching at Auburn University, taking that persona onto Capitol Hill, where he’s affectionately called “coach.” Tuberville would be a formidable candidate in a Republican primary. He’s closely aligned with Trump, and successfully defeated former attorney general Jeff Sessions, who previously held the seat, in the 2020 Republican primary.
The ‘big, beautiful bill’
Elon Musk weighed in on Republicans’ catchall legislation, the One Big Beautiful Bill Act. He doesn’t seem pleased.

The billionaire tasked with slashing federal spending was “disappointed” to see the bill add to the federal deficit, he said in an interview with “CBS Sunday Morning” <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a23/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/29/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> airing this weekend. The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the bill could add $2.3 trillion to the national debt <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42ae598/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/30/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> over 10 years. Musk said the bill “undermines the work that the DOGE team is doing.”

“I think a bill can be big or it can be beautiful, but I don’t know if it can be both. My personal opinion,” Musk said.

The bill passed the House last week, and the Senate will take it up when it returns to Washington next week. Some deficit hawks in the Senate expressed concerns similar to Musk’s, but Republicans are divided, with others demanding protections for clean energy tax cuts and social spending programs.

 

Get ready with The Post
Trump lashed out at the Kremlin on Tuesday <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a24/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/31/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> for its unwillingness to negotiate a ceasefire with Ukraine as he continued to consider increased sanctions against Russia, Michael Birnbaum and Martine Powers report, an escalation from his previously friendly tone toward President Vladimir Putin that came as Trump appeared to grow gloomier about his ability to broker peace in Ukraine.   Trump will also soon pardon a reality television couple <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a25/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/32/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> found guilty of fraud and tax evasion, the White House confirmed on Tuesday. Todd and Julie Chrisley, former stars of the USA Network’s “Chrisley Knows Best,” were sentenced to 12 and seven years, respectively, in 2022.   Trump fired inspectors general at 19 agencies, and some of the replacements he’s named have clearly partisan pasts <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a26/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/33/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>, Meryl Kornfield and Lisa Rein report. Two of them have ties to the agencies they would be overseeing.   Trump previously pitched a millionaires tax as part of Republicans’ major tax and spending cuts bill, but many in the party demurred. Jeff Stein takes us into how Republicans turned on the idea <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a27/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/34/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>.   The CIA needs more spies. Director John Ratcliffe wants to reinvigorate the agency’s human intelligence — traditional spying by agents on the ground — but Warren Strobel and Ellen Nakashima report that human intelligence faces numerous challenges <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a28/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/35/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> in today’s environment, including stronger technical surveillance and a post-covid world.   Postcard from Canada
Britain’s King Charles III, who is also Canada’s king, visited Ottawa yesterday, giving the first speech to Parliament from a Canadian monarch in nearly 50 years. It was a stern assertion of Canada’s sovereignty and widely seen as a rebuke to Trump’s musings about making the country the 51st state.

“Democracy, pluralism, the rule of law, self-determination and freedom are values Canadians hold dear and ones which the government is determined to protect,” Charles said in a speech mixing English and French and opening with an acknowledgment. “The system of open global trade that, while not perfect, has helped to deliver prosperity for Canadians for decades is changing. Canada’s relationship with partners is also changing.”

Charles spent much of the speech, which was written by Canada’s government, stressing the country’s need to navigate a changing world — including alliances that it may have historically taken for granted. He largely avoided mentioning Trump, but he did say the president had productive conversations to define a “new economy and security relationship” with Prime Minister Mark Carney.

“All Canadians can give themselves far more than any foreign power on any continent can ever take away,” Charles said.

Amanda Coletta has more from Toronto <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c6a29/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/36/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>.

 

In your local paper

SpotlightPA (Pennsylvania): Pennsylvania is the last state in the nation to elect poll workers, leading officials to worry that they are short thousands of candidates for the positions <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2a/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/37/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>.

County17 (Gillette, Wyoming): There is an odd, yet public, conflict brewing between <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2b/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/38/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> Wyoming Gov. Mark Gordon (R) and Wyoming Secretary of State Chuck Gray (R). Gordon began publishing a newsletter Friday, alleging that Gray was spreading misinformation that needed to be debunked. “The record needs to be set straight,” Gordon wrote.

The Boston Globe: Tom Morello did not mince his words <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2c/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/39/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> on Trump during a performance this weekend in Boston, where the Rage Against the Machine guitarist called for a revolution and shouted out Harvard and Bruce Springsteen, both subjects of Trump’s ire.

Colorado Public Radio: NPR and some of its Colorado partners sued <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2d/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/40/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37> the Trump administration over an executive order gutting funding for the public radio networks. The networks say Trump is violating their First Amendment rights in a politically motivated attack.
From you
Yesterday, we wrote about how clean energy tax credits created under President Joe Biden could get nixed in Republicans’ mammoth tax and spending cuts bill. The tax credits were the biggest investment in combating climate change in history and the cornerstone of Democrats’ 2022 climate bill.

Paul Grabowski of Alexandria, Virginia, wrote back emphasizing that the federal government also has generous tax incentives for oil and gas production, benefiting the coal, oil and gas industries with more than $12 billion from 2022 to 2026, according to an analysis by the Tax Policy Center. <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2e/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/41/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37>

That’s a great point — the clean energy tax credits weren’t created in a vacuum and had precedent with federal assistance for fossil fuel production.

class="mainByline" valign="middle" style="line-height:normal;mso-line-height-rule:exactly;padding:0 0 16px 0;text-align:left;"> <h6 class="bylineName" style="color:#2a2a2a;font-size:16px !important;margin:0 !important;padding:0 !important;">By <a href="mailto:matthew.choi@washpost.com" style="color: #2a2a2a;">Matthew Choi</a> and <a href="mailto:Dan.Merica@washpost.com" style="color: #2a2a2a;">Dan Merica</a></h6> <span style="color:#494949;font:normal 300 15px/160% 'fl', sans-serif;mso-line-height-rule:exactly;"></span> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <table style="float: none !important;" align="left" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"> <tbody> <tr> <td width="45" height="51" valign="top" align="left"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/28/varied-issues-facing-american-manufacturing/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a19%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F12%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37"><img style="display:block;width:37px;max-width:37px;" width="37" alt="" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/0a008d37153f5777d941cd676a240448-headphone_80px-80-80.png"></a></td> <td valign="middle" align="left" class="iconText"><p><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/28/varied-issues-facing-american-manufacturing/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a19%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F13%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">Listen to this briefing</a></p></td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Good morning, Early Birds. One of us is enjoying the NBA playoffs, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2025/05/27/foul-artists-nba-playoffs-sga-jalen-brunson/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a1a%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F14%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">foul artists</a> and all. Send tips to <a href="mailto:earlytips@washpost.com" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">earlytips@washpost.com</a>. Thanks for waking up with us.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>In today’s edition</b> … King Charles III goes to the mat for Canada … Senate Democrats preview their Medicaid messaging … Sen. Tuberville looks for an exit …<b> </b>but first …</p> <h1>The varied issues facing American manufacturing</h1> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="100%" align="center"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" style="line-height:0;" class="imgCell"> <img style="height:auto !important;max-width:640px !important;width:100%;" width="640" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/7b4c4f447088f6a00c928b206b5d9549-TMPRYVTOLYRM4P3G7U6QK3PG6E-1280-0.jpeg" alt="Donald Trump speaks during a campaign event at the Precision Components Group building in York, Pennsylvania, last year. (Tom Brenner/For The Washington Post)"> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td> <p class="imageCap" style="color: #aaaaaa; font: 12px/120% 'fl', sans-serif; margin: 8px 0 16px;">Donald Trump speaks during a campaign event at the Precision Components Group building in York, Pennsylvania, last year. (Tom Brenner/For The Washington Post)</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">President <b>Donald Trump </b>is pressing to invigorate manufacturing in the United States.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">He said Sunday that his trade policy is aimed at making “big things” in the U.S. again, not just T-shirts and sneakers. “We are looking to do chips and computers and lots of other things, and tanks and ships,” Trump said. To that end, last month, Trump <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1b/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/16/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">signed an executive order</a> aimed at encouraging Americans to go into high-skilled trade jobs.</p> <table width="auto" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr> <td colspan="2" align="center" style="line-height:0;"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=906533&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=static" border="0" style="max-height:12px;"> </td> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" align="left" valign="top" style="padding:0 0 24px 0;line-height:0;font-size:0;" class="natAdTop"> <a href="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=default" target="_blank"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=default&li_coord=desktop&collapse_width=600" width="560" border="0" style="display:block;height:auto;width:100%;max-width:560px;" alt="" class="lihide"> </a> </td> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" align="left" valign="top" style="line-height:0;"> <!--[if !mso]><!--> <div style="display:none; float:left; overflow:hidden; width:0; max-height:0; line-height:0;" class="lishow"> <table width="auto" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="left" valign="top" style="padding:0 0 24px 0;"> <a href="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=default" target="_blank"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37&stpe=default&li_coord=mobile&collapse_width=600" width="100%" border="0" style="display:block;height:auto;" alt="Advertisement"> </a> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </div><!--<![endif]--> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">According to experts and recent examinations of the American labor market, that may not be enough.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">There are major issues facing American manufacturing, and yes, those issues include cheaper labor abroad and trade barriers in other countries, two problems Trump is trying to address through tariffs.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">But his trade policy largely ignores key domestic issues: Widespread job openings that companies are struggling to fill and an aging workforce with millions set to retire over the next decade. The declining size of the American workforce is further exacerbated by the president’s efforts to decrease immigration, particularly in skilled-labor professions.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“This gets into an immigration debate. … We’ll have students from Asia come in to study, but they can’t stay. And so we educate them at taxpayer expense, and then they go back to our competition,” Rep. <b>Michael McCaul </b>(R-Texas) recently told us at a Washington Post Live event on manufacturing. “I had this bill several years ago. If you get a PhD in high-skilled engineering, you get a green card. … I’m not sure how others in the administration may view that now.”</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">There were about 450,000 open manufacturing jobs in March, <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1c/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/19/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics</a>, positions that companies are struggling to fill. And <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1d/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/20/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">a study last year</a> by the Manufacturing Institute — a nonprofit workforce development and education affiliate of the National Association of Manufacturers — and<b> </b>Deloitte found that recruiting and retaining workers was the most pressing issue for top manufacturing companies.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“The U.S. manufacturing industry could see a net need for as many as 3.8 million jobs between 2024 and 2033 as significant investment continues to drive growth,” <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1d/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/21/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">read the report</a>. “Without significant changes, more than 5 in 10 or 1.9 million of these jobs could go unfilled if workforce challenges are not addressed through 2033.”</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Central to that problem is age. The <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1e/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/22/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">average age of a manufacturing worker is 44.3</a> years, older than the 42-year-old average age of all workers in America, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Only<b> </b>8 percent of manufacturing workers are under 25 years old. The Census Bureau also found in 2020 that “nearly one-fourth of the manufacturing workforce is age 55 or older.” And surveys show that <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a1f/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/23/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">few younger Americans are interested in factory work</a>.</p> <table width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr data-hide-when="sample"> <td class="ad-label mobile-border-top" align="center" bgcolor="#F0F0F0" colspan="2" style="background-color:#F0F0F0;border-top:1px solid #cccccc;color:#595959;font:300 16px 'fl', sans-serif;padding:24px 0 11px 0;">Advertisement</td> </tr> <tr data-hide-when="sample"> <td valign="top" align="center" bgcolor="#F0F0F0" style="padding:5px 0 40px;" class="adMainImg"> <table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr> <td colspan="2" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="line-height: normal;"> <a href="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=689175&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" rel="nofollow"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=689175&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" border="0" width="560" style="width: 100%; max-width: 560px !important;" alt="Advertisement"> </a> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td align="center" valign="top" height="24" style="font-size:24px;line-height:24px;border-top:1px solid #cccccc;"> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">To <b>Carolyn Lee</b>, president of the Manufacturing Institute, this is an issue of perception vs. reality.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“The age of the manufacturing workforce has long been a challenge for us,” Lee said. “People don’t understand what manufacturing is all about today. They have this image of something they have seen on television or in the movies. So there is this disconnect between understanding the reality of the sector and what the potential of those jobs are and what people believe them to be. Perception is one of our biggest gaps.”</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">This issue is a political football in nearly every presidential campaign. As states such as Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania have grown in political relevance, so too has the issue of manufacturing, with presidential candidates often sparring over who will be better for the trades.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">A “manufacturing renaissance” was the centerpiece of Trump’s economic policy during his 2024 run. “You will see a mass exodus of manufacturing from China to Pennsylvania, from Korea to North Carolina, from Germany to right here in Georgia,” Trump <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a20/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/25/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">told an audience</a> in that state months before the election.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">But <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a21/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/26/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">analysts at Wells Fargo</a> recently found that “a meaningful increase in factory jobs does not appear likely in the foreseeable future,” because just to bring the industry back to its high point of around 1980, it will cost “at a minimum $2.9 trillion in net new capital investment.”</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“There is no one lever that is going to fix all the things that ails us when it comes to workforce development,” Lee said. “Most people think of manufacturing that you are standing on an assembly line and doing a single manual function and that is 40 years of your career. And that is far from the truth. That is why we need to tell the story of manufacturing jobs.”</p> <h1>On the campaign trail</h1> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Senate Democrats are looking to make the sweeping spending bill passed by the House a political cudgel, <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a22/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/27/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">launching a digital ad campaign</a> today that ties Senate Republicans to the House bill that would cut Medicaid spending and lock in tax cuts for higher earners.</p> <table width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr data-hide-when="sample"> <td class="ad-label mobile-border-top" align="center" bgcolor="#F0F0F0" colspan="2" style="background-color:#F0F0F0;border-top:1px solid #cccccc;color:#595959;font:300 16px 'fl', sans-serif;padding:24px 0 11px 0;">Advertisement</td> </tr> <tr data-hide-when="sample"> <td valign="top" align="center" bgcolor="#F0F0F0" style="padding:5px 0 40px;" class="adMainImg"> <table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr> <td colspan="2" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="line-height: normal;"> <a href="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=689179&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" rel="nofollow"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=689179&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" border="0" width="560" style="width: 100%; max-width: 560px !important;" alt="Advertisement"> </a> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td align="center" valign="top" height="24" style="font-size:24px;line-height:24px;border-top:1px solid #cccccc;"> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">The 60-second digital spot — titled “Devastating” — will run on Meta platforms and a range of digital TV channels. It shows a simple Google search asking, “What’s happening with the Republican budget,” followed by news reports on what the bill’s Medicaid cuts would mean for states and how taxes would go down for top earners. <i>“</i>The Republican budget is wrong for American families,” a text block reads at the end of the spot.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">The ad highlights how the months-long work by the House will probably become a central point of Democratic messaging in the 2026 midterms, whether or not the Senate changes the bill in the coming weeks.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“Under the leadership of Senate Republicans, millions of people are at risk of losing their health insurance — and voters will hold them accountable for it at the ballot box in 2026,” committee spokeswoman <b>Maeve Coyle </b>said.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>In other campaign news:</b> Sen. <b>Tommy Tuberville</b> (R-Alabama) is officially running for governor after weeks of anticipation. He had been hinting at a run but made it official during an interview on Fox News yesterday.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“I’m a football coach. I’m a leader. I’m a builder. I’m a recruiter, and we’re going to grow Alabama,” Tuberville said. “We’re going to bring manufacturing to this state. We’re going to stop this illegal immigration.”</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Tuberville is a first-term senator who was elected in 2020 after a career coaching at Auburn University, taking that persona onto Capitol Hill, where he’s affectionately called “coach.” Tuberville would be a formidable candidate in a Republican primary. He’s closely aligned with Trump, and successfully defeated former attorney general <b>Jeff Sessions</b>, who previously held the seat, in the 2020 Republican primary.</p> <h1>The ‘big, beautiful bill’</h1> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>Elon Musk </b>weighed in on Republicans’ catchall legislation, the One Big Beautiful Bill Act. He doesn’t seem pleased.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">The billionaire tasked with slashing federal spending was “disappointed” to see the bill add to the federal deficit, he said in an <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a23/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/29/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">interview with “CBS Sunday Morning”</a> airing this weekend. The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the bill <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/05/21/medicare-cuts-big-beautiful-bill-republicans-house/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42ae598%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F30%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">could add $2.3 trillion to the national debt</a> over 10 years. Musk said the bill “undermines the work that the DOGE team is doing.”</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“I think a bill can be big or it can be beautiful, but I don’t know if it can be both. My personal opinion,” Musk said.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">The bill passed the House last week, and the Senate will take it up when it returns to Washington next week. Some deficit hawks in the Senate expressed concerns similar to Musk’s, but Republicans are divided, with others demanding protections for clean energy tax cuts and social spending programs.</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="left" style="max-width:87.5%"> <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" align="center" style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" colspan="2" valign="top" height="30" style="border-bottom:1px solid #555555;font-size:30px;line-height:30px;"> </td> </tr> <tr> <td width="43" height="40" valign="top" align="left" style="padding:8px 0 20px 0;"> <img style="display:block;width:35px;max-width:35px;" width="35" alt="" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/a9192f43c32eb694029efbba4cf58a0e-nl-theearlybrief-campaignicon_tstmp_1714668928-101-101.png"> </td> <td align="left"> <h4 style="background-color:#ffffff;color:#000000;padding:6px 0 12px 0;">Get ready with The Post</h4> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <ul> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;">Trump <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/27/trump-putin-ukraine-sanctions-ceasefire/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a24%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F31%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">lashed out at the Kremlin on Tuesday</a> for its unwillingness to negotiate a ceasefire with Ukraine as he continued to consider increased sanctions against Russia, <b>Michael Birnbaum</b> and <b>Martine Powers</b> report, an escalation from his previously friendly tone toward President <b>Vladimir Putin</b> that came as Trump appeared to grow gloomier about his ability to broker peace in Ukraine.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;">Trump will also <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/27/trump-pardon-chrisley/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a25%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F32%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">soon pardon a reality television couple</a> found guilty of fraud and tax evasion, the White House confirmed on Tuesday. <b>Todd </b>and<b> Julie Chrisley</b>, former stars of the USA Network’s “Chrisley Knows Best,” were sentenced to 12 and seven years, respectively, in 2022.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;">Trump fired inspectors general at 19 agencies, and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/28/trump-inspectors-general-scandal-partisan/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a26%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F33%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">some of the replacements he’s named have clearly partisan pasts</a>,<b> Meryl Kornfield </b>and <b>Lisa Rein</b> report. Two of them have ties to the agencies they would be overseeing.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;">Trump previously pitched a millionaires tax as part of Republicans’ major tax and spending cuts bill, but many in the party demurred. <b>Jeff Stein</b> takes us into <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/05/28/gop-tax-bill-trump-millionaire-tax/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a27%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F34%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">how Republicans turned on the idea</a>.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;">The CIA needs more spies. Director <b>John Ratcliffe </b>wants to reinvigorate the agency’s human intelligence — traditional spying by agents on the ground — but <b>Warren Strobel </b>and <b>Ellen Nakashima </b>report that <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2025/05/28/cia-spy-china-russia-ratcliffe/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a28%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F35%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">human intelligence faces numerous challenges</a> in today’s environment, including stronger technical surveillance and a post-covid world.</li> </ul> <h1>Postcard from Canada</h1> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Britain’s King <b>Charles III</b>, who is also Canada’s king, visited Ottawa yesterday, giving the first speech to Parliament from a Canadian monarch in nearly 50 years. It was a stern assertion of Canada’s sovereignty and widely seen as a rebuke to Trump’s musings about making the country the 51st state.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“Democracy, pluralism, the rule of law, self-determination and freedom are values Canadians hold dear and ones which the government is determined to protect,” Charles said in a speech mixing English and French and opening with an acknowledgment. “The system of open global trade that, while not perfect, has helped to deliver prosperity for Canadians for decades is changing. Canada’s relationship with partners is also changing.”</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Charles spent much of the speech, which was written by Canada’s government, stressing the country’s need to navigate a changing world — including alliances that it may have historically taken for granted. He largely avoided mentioning Trump, but he did say the president had productive conversations to define a “new economy and security relationship” with<b> </b>Prime Minister <b>Mark Carney</b>.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“All Canadians can give themselves far more than any foreign power on any continent can ever take away,” Charles said.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>Amanda Coletta</b> <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/05/27/canada-king-charles-canada-parliament/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c6a29%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F36%2F56%2F6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">has more from Toronto</a>.</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="left" style="max-width:87.5%"> <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" align="center" style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" colspan="2" valign="top" height="30" style="border-bottom:1px solid #555555;font-size:30px;line-height:30px;"> </td> </tr> <tr> <td width="43" height="40" valign="top" align="left" style="padding:8px 0 20px 0;"> <img style="display:block;width:35px;max-width:35px;" width="35" alt="" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/271b0fcfbb7724b824caf58dac719945-nl-theearlybrief-OnKStreeticon_tstmp_1714668928-101-101.png"> </td> <td align="left"> <h4 style="background-color:#ffffff;color:#000000;padding:6px 0 12px 0;">In your local paper</h4> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>SpotlightPA (Pennsylvania): </b>Pennsylvania is the last state in the nation to elect poll workers, leading officials to worry that <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2a/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/37/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">they are short thousands of candidates for the positions</a>.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>County17 (Gillette, Wyoming): </b>There is an odd, yet public, <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2b/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/38/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">conflict brewing between</a> Wyoming Gov. <b>Mark Gordon</b> (R) and Wyoming Secretary of State <b>Chuck Gray</b> (R). Gordon began publishing a newsletter Friday, alleging that Gray was spreading misinformation that needed to be debunked. “The record needs to be set straight,” Gordon wrote.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>The Boston Globe: </b>Tom Morello <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2c/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/39/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">did not mince his words</a> on Trump during a performance this weekend in Boston, where the Rage Against the Machine guitarist called for a revolution and shouted out Harvard and Bruce Springsteen, both subjects of Trump’s ire.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>Colorado Public Radio:</b> <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2d/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/40/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">NPR and some of its Colorado partners sued</a> the Trump administration over an executive order gutting funding for the public radio networks. The networks say Trump is violating their First Amendment rights in a politically motivated attack.</p> <h1>From you</h1> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Yesterday, we wrote about how clean energy tax credits created under President <b>Joe Biden</b> could get nixed in Republicans’ mammoth tax and spending cuts bill. The tax credits were the biggest investment in combating climate change in history and the cornerstone of Democrats’ 2022 climate bill.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>Paul Grabowski</b> of Alexandria, Virginia, wrote back emphasizing that the federal government also has generous tax incentives for oil and gas production, benefiting the coal, oil and gas industries with more than $12 billion from 2022 to 2026, according to an analysis by the <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c6a2e/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/41/56/6836e2ff74393667ca1aed37" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">Tax Policy Center.</a></p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">That’s a great point — the clean energy tax credits weren’t created in a vacuum and had precedent with federal assistance for fossil fuel production.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">If you ever have feedback for us, please feel free to reach out at earlytips@washpost.com!</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="left" style="max-width:87.5%"> <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" align="center" style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" colspan="2" valign="top" height="30" style="border-bottom:1px solid #555555;font-size:30px;line-height:30px;"> </td> </tr> <tr> <td width="43" height="40" valign="top" align="left" style="padding:8px 0 20px 0;"> <img style="display:block;width:35px;max-width:35px;" width="35" alt="" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/a9192f43c32eb694029efbba4cf58a0e-nl-theearlybrief-campaignicon_tstmp_1714668928-101-101.png"> </td> <td align="left"> <h4 style="background-color:#ffffff;color:#000000;padding:6px 0 12px 0;">Send a reply</h4> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">We will be writing about the movement for a national popular vote later this week. 39.subject: ✏️ La viñeta de la semana: en Hungría, Viktor Orbán vuelve a atacar a los medios de comunicación
39.body:
[Ver en el navegador](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/mr/sh/SMK3Houzc6wTjKrlyNGwOUUoX2YM/_nvfxv_KCR4v) 28 mayo 2025 La viñeta de la semana ====================== [**En Hungría, Viktor Orbán vuelve a atacar a los medios de comunicación**](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/6rqKAbwSw85lZB1ZuzgnnfqFsnK/sb2SELY6RMBT) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ [**Ramsés Morales Izquierdo - Cartoon movement (Amsterdam)**](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/6rqKAbwSwExDhzyl59AtcyaEBNa/MpdurHHsyNJz) ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- El gobierno de extrema derecha de Viktor Orbán continúa su asalto a los derechos fundamentales en Hungría. El último ataque es[ un proyecto de ley](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/6rqKAbwSwSg7zdt7PS95Ha4AmY6/Fo9YUc8Rwey3) destinado a multar a los medios de comunicación y a las organizaciones que reciban financiación del exterior y “amenacen la soberanía nacional”. El proyecto de ley (en la misma línea que [la ley rusa sobre agentes extranjeros](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/6rqKAbwSwZXa8SqIZbdB6so958M/JI2kSUEgIYXY)) permitiría imponer sanciones económicas de hasta 25 veces el importe de los fondos recibidos, en un claro intento de restringir la libertad de prensa.   Las organizaciones de la sociedad civil y los medios de comunicación independientes en el país y en toda la Unión Europea se han alzado contra el gobierno de Orbán. Esta semana republicamos un [llamamiento](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/6rqKAbwSwgP2HHnTjl7GwBY7Nic/CovWB1EHlUOe) firmado por casi un centenar de redactores jefe (y por Voxeurop) en el que se pide a las autoridades europeas que tomen cartas en el asunto e impongan sanciones a Hungría.   A un año de las próximas elecciones legislativas, Budapest redobla sus esfuerzos para controlar la sociedad. Este proyecto de ley sobre la transparencia de los medios de comunicación no es el primero de este tipo: en marzo se aprobó otro que [prohíbe](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/6rqKAbwSwnGUQ6ketubMlUI5gIs/-IMBd8an9kTL) las concentraciones a favor de los derechos de las personas LGBTQIA+.     [*Adrian Burtin*](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/6rqKAbwSwu7wYvhq445San23yt8/QQYOcZqAe62j) [*Periodista y editor*](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/6rqKAbwSx0zOhkf1EDZYQ5m2HTO/nL12iDwM_CXY) ¿Tienes alguna duda sobre nuestro trabajo? **Las puertas de la redacción están abiertas**: [reserva un encuentro](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/SMK3HofPU2xOpjCF9XZIUDvXupf8/td0zBAryZYSK) virtual de 20 minutos para hablar con una persona del equipo. [ **👉 Reservar una cita**](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/SMK3HofPUVI729abFSjYY3JMtZNC/ps_lERGj2TDZ) 💛 ¿Te ha gustado? Apóyanos.   **Una**[**donación**](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/SMK3HofPUxcpEZyxLNtobshBsJ5G/orIt_zUGVZXh)**puntual marca la diferencia. Una regular** **garantiza nuestra independencia.** [ **Hacer una donación 💛**](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/SMK3HofPVPxXR0NJRJ44fi50r2nK/DKqmrC_TajPc) La viñeta de prensa forma parte de la historia de Voxeurop. La consideramos un formato periodístico por derecho propio que vehicula mensajes firmes y a menudo universales, capaz de ir más allá de los idiomas y las fronteras. Mientras que muchas redacciones lo han abandonado, nuestro objetivo siempre ha sido valorizarlo y apoyarlo a través de nuestra asociación con [Cartoon Movement](https://3s845.r.ah.d.sendibm5.com/mk/cl/f/sh/SMK3HofPVsIFdQlfXEEKjXSppmVO/la7Z1VP_nCu7).    *A partir de ahora, **cada miércoles por la mañana** te enviaremos por email la viñeta que seleccionarmos para ilustrar la actualidad de la semana, con un texto de acompañamiento. Un formato simple que puedes **leer en menos de un minuto** mientras desayunas, vas en transporte público o miras el buzón.*   ***Ya no aparecerá en la newsletter semanal que recibes los jueves**. Si prefieres no recibir la viñeta en este formato, puedes desinscribirte aquí abajo.
