43.subject: The Cipher Brief Nightcap for Tuesday May 27, 2025
43.body:
View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/thecipherbrief/the-cipher-brief-nightcap-for-tuesday-may-27-2025?e=55bbe501e9)
https://www.thecipherbrief.com?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID

X (https://twitter.com/thecipherbrief?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID)  | LINKEDIN  (https://www.linkedin.com/company/thecipherbrief/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) | INSTAGRAM (https://www.instagram.com/thecipherbrief/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID)  | FACEBOOK (http://www.facebook.com/thecipherbrief?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID)  I YOU TUBE (https://youtube.com/@thecipherbrief?si=fAHGxQkFuY455beu&utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID)  I BLUE SKY (https://bsky.app/profile/thecipherbrief.bsky.social?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID)

thecipherbrief.com (https://www.thecipherbrief.com?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID)

Tuesday / May 27 / 2025
What you need to know tonight about national and global security

SEVERAL TOP CISA OFFICIALS GONE OR HEADED OUT — The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is facing more upheaval and uncertainty. Several of the cybersecurity agency’s senior officials (https://www.cybersecuritydive.com/news/cisa-senior-official-departures/748992/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID#:~:text=The%20leaders%20of%20CISA's%20field,Region%2010%20Director%20Patrick%20Massey) have recently left their positions, or will soon be out the door.

An email sent Thursday by CISA deputy director Madhu Gottumukkala, and first reported on by The Washington Post (https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2025/05/23/cisa-cyberattacks-china-doge-cuts/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID#:~:text=In%20a%20memo,resources%20and%20contracting.) , details the departures. The top leaders (https://www.nextgov.com/people/2025/05/top-cisa-division-chiefs-depart-amid-broader-agency-reduction-plans/405603/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID#:~:text=Regional%20chiefs%20including%20John%20Durkin,CISA%20deputy%20director%20Madhu%20Gottumukkala) of five of CISA’s six operational divisions and six of its 10 regional offices will all be gone by the end of the month. The vacancies hit CISA’s infrastructure security, stakeholder engagement, emergency communications, cybersecurity and integrated operations divisions, as well as the regional teams that expand CISA’s nationwide presence. Several administrative officials have also left or are leaving.

The email did not specify the reasons for the departures.

The leadership exodus comes as the Trump administration has been working to cut CISA’s workforce (https://www.cbsnews.com/news/cisa-cybersecurity-election-infrastructure-face-significant-cuts-sources-say/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) and budget (https://www.govinfosecurity.com/white-house-proposes-500-million-cut-to-cisa-a-28216?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID#:~:text=It%20remains%20unclear%20how%20exactly,to%20a%20request%20for%20comment.) . Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Secretary Kristi Noem has said that the changes aim to get CISA “back on mission” and refocus the agency on boosting cyber resilience of critical infrastructure and covering Chinese cyber threats — rather than having it look at disinformation campaigns traced to Russia and China.

When asked about the email, CISA Executive Director Bridget Bean maintained that the agency is fulfilling its cyber defense mission despite the changes. “CISA is doubling down and fulfilling its statutory mission to secure the nation’s critical infrastructure and strengthen our collective cyber defense,” Bean said. “We were created to be the cybersecurity agency for the nation, and we have the right team in place to fulfill that mission and ensure that we are prepared for a range of cyber threats from our adversaries.”

Several cybersecurity experts and officials have raised concerns about the impact of cuts to CISA, noting that the changes are coming at a time when the threat in cyberspace is at an all-time high.

One CISA employee said, “All of these departures make it feel like people are leaving the mission and creating a vacuum (https://www.cybersecuritydive.com/news/cisa-senior-official-departures/748992/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID#:~:text=The%20leaders%20of%20CISA%27s%20field,Region%2010%20Director%20Patrick%20Massey) .”

Suzanne Spaulding, a Cyber Initiatives Group Principal who led CISA’s predecessor wing in the DHS, warned that “The loss of these leaders, including leaders across the country who work every day with the owners and operators of critical infrastructure, will leave the nation less secure and resilient (https://www.cybersecuritydive.com/news/cisa-senior-official-departures/748992/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID#:~:text=The%20leaders%20of%20CISA%27s%20field,Region%2010%20Director%20Patrick%20Massey) .”

Experts also noted that the Trump administration has repeatedly signaled its focus on and recognition of the importance of cybersecurity, both in terms of resilience and deterrence. But they say the administration needs to swiftly work through any restructuring to have that “core mission” focus take effect.

“Our adversaries are not waiting,” Colin Ahern, Chief Cyber Office for the State of New York, told The Cipher Brief (https://www.thecipherbrief.com/new-york-chief-cyber-officer-u-s-falling-behind-and-adversaries-arent-waiting?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) . “Our adversaries are not standing by. Our adversaries are conducting ransomware attacks against our businesses, our schools, our hospitals each and every day. The Chinese in particular are continuing to wantonly steal intellectual property. And so unfortunately, we're not in a situation where we can wait. I think time is of the essence.”

TRUMP SAYS PUTIN ‘PLAYING WITH FIRE’ — President Donald Trump expressed increasing frustration with Russian President Vladimir Putin over Russia’s attacks on Ukraine, as U.S. efforts for a peace deal stall.

“What Vladimir Putin doesn’t realize is that if it weren’t for me, lots of really bad things would have already happened to Russia, and I mean REALLY BAD. He’s playing with fire! (https://www.wsj.com/world/russia/trump-putin-russia-sanctions-truth-social-79738b06?mod=world_lead_story&utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) ” President Trump wrote Tuesday on Truth Social.

The latest post follows President Trump’s comments on Sunday, when he unloaded on the Russian leader, calling him “absolutely CRAZY” and warning that if Putin did not back down from his pursuit of seizing all of Ukraine, it would “lead to the downfall of Russia.”

The marked shift in rhetoric (https://www.politico.com/news/2025/05/27/trump-putin-attack-ukraine-00370919?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) followed massive Russian attacks on Ukraine. Ukrainian officials said Russia launched over 900 drones and 92 missiles in attacks over the weekend. President Trump said Putin was “needlessly killing a lot of people” with the attacks, which he described as being launched “for no reason whatsoever.”

The Kremlin said the strikes were retaliation for Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian territory. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov played down President Trump’s criticism, blaming them on “emotional overload” and thanking him for leading U.S. efforts to end the war.

The past few days have seen a change in tone from President Trump, who had previously refrained from harsh criticism of the Russian leader, and took a far more sympathetic stance to Moscow than his predecessors. That said, Trump’s words have yet to translate to any changes in policy – only a warning that he is considering more sanctions against Russia. Both the Senate and the House are considering legislation for new sanctions on Moscow.

WARNING OF RUSSIAN SUMMER OFFENSIVES — As President Trump slammed Putin, Russian forces made advances on the battlefield in Ukraine. Sumy Governor Oleh Hryhorov wrote on Facebook that four villages — Novenke, Basivka, Vezelivka and Zhuravka — have all been occupied by Russian forces (https://www.reuters.com/world/ukrainian-governor-says-russian-forces-capture-four-villages-sumy-2025-05-26/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) in recent days, though their residents had been evacuated some time ago. Russia’s Defense Ministry said on Monday that its forces had also taken the nearby village of Bilovody. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has repeatedly warned of further Russian offensive operations against targets in Sumy, as well as the northeastern Kharkiv and southeastern Zaporizhzhia regions.

Ukrainian military officials and analysts warn that Russia is expected to launch a new major summer offensive in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region (https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/05/27/ukraine-russia-summer-offensive/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

REPORT: RUSSIA PLANNING REBOOT OF UKRAINIAN NUCLEAR POWER PLANT — Russia is building power lines in occupied southeastern Ukraine to connect Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, which Russia has captured, to its own grid, according to a new Greenpeace report cited by the New York Times (https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/27/world/europe/russia-ukraine-nuclear-zaporizhzhia.html?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

The Times cites the construction as evidence that Moscow means to use the power plant to generate electricity for territory it now controls.

Satellite images published by Greenpeace show that since early February, Russia has built more than 50 miles of electricity lines and pylons between the occupied Ukrainian cities of Mariupol and Berdyansk, along the coast of the Azov Sea. Greenpeace said the new power lines appeared to link to a large substation near Mariupol that is connected to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant,
The Times reported that if Russia restarts Zaporizhzhia for its own purposes, that would conflict with the Trump administration’s recent efforts to include the fate of the plant as part of possible peace talks.

A White House peace (https://www.reuters.com/world/ukraine-peace-deal-proposals-set-out-by-us-talks-paris-2025-04-25/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) plan (https://www.axios.com/2025/04/22/trump-russia-ukraine-peace-plan-crimea-donbas?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) presented last month proposed that Russia would return the plant to Ukraine and that it would be put under U.S. management, to supply electricity to both Ukraine and Russia. Russia has rejected the idea. Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov told CBS News (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qIkzReERAcM&ab_channel=FacetheNation&utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) that the Zaporizhzhia plant was being run by the Russian nuclear power company Rosatom and that he did not think “any change is conceivable.”
Join the Special Competitive Studies Project (https://www.scsp.ai/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID)  on June 2-4, 2025, for the AI+ Expo in Washington, DC! Build meaningful connections with attendees from government, industry, and academia at this premier AI and emerging tech event. Experience live races at the Drone Arena, join the Hackathon where $135k in prize value will be awarded, explore career pathways at the ai+careers stage, and discover insightful reads at the Bookstore. Register now for free (https://expo.scsp.ai/?utm_medium=digital_ad&utm_source=The%20Cipher%20Brief&utm_campaign=aiexpo25&utm_content=may-june&utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID)
When you’re done soaking in the genius (and we mean that) on display at SCSP in Washington next week, consider jumping on a plane to Austin, Texas for The Cipher Brief’s NatSecEDGE Conference (http://www.natsecedge.com/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) , where experts will be focusing on investing in future U.S. national security. Many of the heaviest hitters will be there, including Allen& Co., Apollo, Palantir, Crumpton Ventures, and dozens and dozens more organizations that are skating to the puck when it comes to future national security.  Just imagine what you’ll miss by not being in the room.

EUROPE FACES QUESTIONS ABOUT ITS OWN DEFENSE — Amid shifts in U.S. security policy away from Europe – and in some cases towards Moscow – officials and experts are raising questions about whether Europe can defend itself. General Philip Breedlove, a Cipher Brief expert who served as the Supreme Allied Commander for Europe, recently completed a multi-country tour of the continent as it grapples with these questions about U.S. commitments. He spoke with The Cipher Brief about broad European military needs, and the specific requirements of so-called frontline European states in countering threats from Russia.

“Deterrence is in the mind of the deterred, and clearly most people like me think about deterrence,” General Breedlove said. “They think of capability and credibility. I think the West and NATO have plenty of capability to deter Mr. Putin. I do not think the West has the credibility to deter Mr. Putin right now, and that’s worrisome… I think Mr. Putin senses weakness and he knows what to do in the presence of weakness.”

Read more in The Cipher Brief (https://www.thecipherbrief.com/as-u-s-commitment-wanes-europe-faces-questions-about-its-own-defense?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

ITALIAN MAFIA GROUPS JOINING FORCES — Italian traditional organized crime groups, including the Cosa Nostra, Camorra and 'Ndrangheta (https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ndrangheta-italys-most-powerful-mafia-group-2023-05-03/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) , have begun fighting less and collaborating more (https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/italys-mafia-abandoning-rivalries-join-forces-report-says-2025-05-27/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) , Italy’s national anti-mafia agency (DIA) said in its annual report. Increased cooperation between the mafia groups could bolster their power and heighten the transnational crime risk in Europe.

The report highlighted that the mafia groups are increasingly involved in trying to control public works projects. "Coexistence has fostered synergies that have progressively become structured," DIA director Michele Carbone told a press conference. He cited concerns about mafia tentacles invading public works linked to Italy's EU-backed post-COVID Recovery Fund, construction of a bridge connecting Sicily to the mainland, and preparations for the 2026 Winter Olympics.

The DIA also noted that the mafia groups are increasing their technological prowess to improve operations, using technologies like encrypted communications and drones — something also seen in Mexican cartels, which The Cipher Brief (https://www.thecipherbrief.com/can-the-cia-and-u-s-military-stop-the-mexican-cartels?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) has reported on.

CHINA BOOSTING PROTECTION OF MILITARY-INDUSTRIAL ASSETS — China issued new rules to boost the protection of military-industrial facilities (https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3311959/china-introduces-rules-protect-military-industrial-assets-spies-and-sabotage?module=top_story&pgtype=section&utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) from espionage and sabotage. The new rules label facilities engaged in research, production, testing and storage of important weapons and equipment for China’s military as “protected areas.” The designation aims to boost the safety and secrecy of the listed facilities by making any act of disruption attempted spying punishable by law.

China’s heightened defensive measures aren’t unexpected. The U.S. is also heightening its guard against potential spying or sabotage amid the escalating military and technology competition with Beijing.

U.S. CONSIDERING FUTURE OF AFRICA MILITARY COMMAND — The future of AFRICOM (https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/us-weighing-future-military-command-africa-top-general-says-2025-05-27/?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) , the U.S. military command for Africa, is in flux. General Michael Langley, AFRICOM’s commander, told reporters before a conference of African defense chiefs in Kenya that the U.S. is taking a closer look at what the military command will look like going forward. His comments come after reports that the U.S. military is shifting its approach in Africa, urging local allies to take greater responsibility for their own security (https://apnews.com/article/us-military-africa-langley-exercises-8a7adb77f13bf1c9b3271577674863cf?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) — a dynamic comparable to the U.S. approach in Europe.

General Langley told reporters that he has asked African counterparts and interlocutors to make clear their views about what the future of AFRICOM should be: "That's what I tell them. I said: 'Okay, if we're that important to (you), you need to communicate that and we'll see'.”

AFRICOM was founded in 2007 to better address rising national security concerns in Africa, from Islamist insurgencies to competition with Russia and China.

In recent years, U.S. and allied security influence in West Africa has waned; the Sahel states of Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso all forced the withdrawal of U.S. and allied Western troops following a series of military coups. Russia has been moving to fill the gap left by the Western pullout. Militant Islamist groups — some with ties to al Qaeda and Islamic State — have been on the rise in the region amid the resulting power vacuum. General Langley said that despite the reduced U.S. influence in the Sahel region, Washington maintains some intelligence sharing with the military juntas there and is looking for “other ways to continue to stay engaged.”

A LESSER-KNOWN BATTLE OF D-DAY — The D-Day invasion of Normandy – more than eight decades ago – played out in theaters beyond the famed beaches at Normandy. In the nearby French town of St. Mere Eglise, troopers of the 82nd Airborne Division captured and held the small La Fiere bridge to prevent German reserves from counterattack U.S. forces at the beach landing. The battle for the bridge is the subject of James Donovan’s latest book “Nothing But Courage (https://www.thecipherbrief.com/book-review/airborne-all-the-way?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) .” Major General (Ret.) Jack Leide, a veteran of 37 years of service in the U.S. Army, who served as a combat airborne infantry and intelligence officer in the 82nd Airborne Division, reviews the book in The Cipher Brief.

“Donovan set out to tell the full story of one of the most operationally critical, although lesser-known, stories of World War II and one that would play a key part particularly in the eventual success of the D-day landings,” Major General Leide writes. “His book is filled, end to end, with incredibly researched depictions of valor by the paratroopers and glider-men of the 82nd Airborne Division.”

Read the full review in The Cipher Brief (https://www.thecipherbrief.com/book-review/airborne-all-the-way?utm_source=The+Cipher+Brief+Nightcap+Newsletter&utm_campaign=95d298e278-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2025_05_27_09_55&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-95d298e278-122460985&mc_cid=95d298e278&mc_eid=UNIQID) .

<!--

</table><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" class="mcnTextBlock" style="min-width: 100%;border-collapse: collapse;mso-table-lspace: 0pt;mso-table-rspace: 0pt;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;">
    <tbody class="mcnTextBlockOuter">
        <tr>
            <td valign="top" class="mcnTextBlockInner" style="padding-top: 9px;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;">
              	<!--[if mso]>
				<table align="left" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="width:100%;">
				<tr>
				<![endif]-->
			
				<!--[if mso]>
				<td valign="top" width="600" style="width:600px;">
				<![endif]-->
                <table align="left" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="max-width: 100%;min-width: 100%;border-collapse: collapse;mso-table-lspace: 0pt;mso-table-rspace: 0pt;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;float: left;" width="100%" class="mcnTextContentContainer">
                    <tbody><tr>

                        <td valign="top" class="mcnTextContent" style="padding-top: 0;padding-right: 18px;padding-bottom: 9px;padding-left: 18px;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;word-break: break-word;color: #202020;font-family: Arial, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size: 16px;line-height: 125%;text-align: left;">

                            <p dir="ltr" style="margin: 10px 0;padding: 0;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #202020;font-family: Arial, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size: 16px;line-height: 125%;text-align: left;"><strong>SEVERAL TOP CISA OFFICIALS GONE OR HEADED OUT — </strong>The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is facing more upheaval and uncertainty. Several of the cybersecurity agency’s <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=b7eaa6a1a2&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">senior officials</a> have recently left their positions, or will soon be out the door. <br>
 <br>
An email sent Thursday by CISA deputy director <strong>Madhu Gottumukkala</strong>, and first reported on by <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=e5ad234d01&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;"><em>The Washington Post</em></a>, details the departures. The <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=902f4dd79a&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">top leaders</a> of five of CISA’s six operational divisions and six of its 10 regional offices will all be gone by the end of the month. The vacancies hit CISA’s infrastructure security, stakeholder engagement, emergency communications, cybersecurity and integrated operations divisions, as well as the regional teams that expand CISA’s nationwide presence. Several administrative officials have also left or are leaving. <br>
 <br>
The email did not specify the reasons for the departures.<br>
 <br>
The leadership exodus comes as the Trump administration has been working to cut CISA’s <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=1b455aceb4&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">workforce</a> and <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=3a7a538683&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">budget</a>. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Secretary <strong>Kristi Noem</strong> has said that the changes aim to get CISA “back on mission” and refocus the agency on boosting cyber resilience of critical infrastructure and covering Chinese cyber threats — rather than having it look at disinformation campaigns traced to Russia and China. <br>
 <br>
When asked about the email, CISA Executive Director <strong>Bridget Bean </strong>maintained that the agency is fulfilling its cyber defense mission despite the changes. “CISA is doubling down and fulfilling its statutory mission to secure the nation’s critical infrastructure and strengthen our collective cyber defense,” Bean said. “We were created to be the cybersecurity agency for the nation, and we have the right team in place to fulfill that mission and ensure that we are prepared for a range of cyber threats from our adversaries.”<br>
 <br>
Several cybersecurity experts and officials have raised concerns about the impact of cuts to CISA, noting that the changes are coming at a time when the threat in cyberspace is at an all-time high. <br>
 <br>
One CISA employee said, “All of these departures make it feel like people are leaving the mission and <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=34b19fc974&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">creating a vacuum</a>.”<br>
 <br>
<strong>Suzanne Spaulding</strong>, a Cyber Initiatives Group Principal who led CISA’s predecessor wing in the DHS, warned that “The loss of these leaders, including leaders across the country who work every day with the owners and operators of critical infrastructure, will leave the nation <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=c92291838b&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">less secure and resilient</a>.”<br>
 <br>
Experts also noted that the Trump administration has repeatedly signaled its focus on and recognition of the importance of cybersecurity, both in terms of resilience and deterrence. But they say the administration needs to swiftly work through any restructuring to have that “core mission” focus take effect.<br>
 <br>
“Our adversaries are not waiting,” <strong>Colin Ahern</strong>, Chief Cyber Office for the State of New York, told <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=74a01eefc1&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;"><em>The Cipher Brief</em></a>. “Our adversaries are not standing by. Our adversaries are conducting ransomware attacks against our businesses, our schools, our hospitals each and every day. The Chinese in particular are continuing to wantonly steal intellectual property. And so unfortunately, we're not in a situation where we can wait. I think time is of the essence.”<br>
 <br>
<strong>TRUMP SAYS PUTIN ‘PLAYING WITH FIRE’ — </strong>President <strong>Donald Trump </strong>expressed increasing frustration with Russian President <strong>Vladimir Putin </strong>over Russia’s attacks on Ukraine, as U.S. efforts for a peace deal stall. <br>
 <br>
“What Vladimir Putin doesn’t realize is that if it weren’t for me, lots of really bad things would have already happened to Russia, and I mean REALLY BAD. <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=451fa6da84&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">He’s playing with fire!</a>” President Trump wrote Tuesday on Truth Social.<br>
 <br>
The latest post follows President Trump’s comments on Sunday, when he unloaded on the Russian leader, calling him “absolutely CRAZY” and warning that if Putin did not back down from his pursuit of seizing all of Ukraine, it would “lead to the downfall of Russia.”<br>
 <br>
The marked <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=b680437182&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">shift in rhetoric</a> followed massive Russian attacks on Ukraine. Ukrainian officials said Russia launched over 900 drones and 92 missiles in attacks over the weekend. President Trump said Putin was “needlessly killing a lot of people” with the attacks, which he described as being launched “for no reason whatsoever.” <br>
 <br>
The Kremlin said the strikes were retaliation for Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian territory. Kremlin spokesman <strong>Dmitry Peskov </strong>played down President Trump’s criticism, blaming them on “emotional overload” and thanking him for leading U.S. efforts to end the war. <br>
 <br>
The past few days have seen a change in tone from President Trump, who had previously refrained from harsh criticism of the Russian leader, and took a far more sympathetic stance to Moscow than his predecessors. That said, Trump’s words have yet to translate to any changes in policy – only a warning that he is considering more sanctions against Russia. Both the Senate and the House are considering legislation for new sanctions on Moscow.<br>
 <br>
<strong>WARNING OF RUSSIAN SUMMER OFFENSIVES — </strong>As President Trump slammed Putin, Russian forces made advances on the battlefield in Ukraine. Sumy Governor <strong>Oleh Hryhorov </strong>wrote on Facebook that four villages — Novenke, Basivka, Vezelivka and Zhuravka — have all been <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=340d50fa75&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">occupied by Russian forces</a> in recent days, though their residents had been evacuated some time ago. Russia’s Defense Ministry said on Monday that its forces had also taken the nearby village of Bilovody. Ukrainian President <strong>Volodymyr Zelensky </strong>has repeatedly warned of further Russian offensive operations against targets in Sumy, as well as the northeastern Kharkiv and southeastern Zaporizhzhia regions. <br>
 <br>
Ukrainian military officials and analysts warn that Russia is expected to launch a new major summer offensive in Ukraine’s eastern <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=2af8f0a96f&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">Donetsk region</a>. <br>
 <br>
<strong>REPORT: RUSSIA PLANNING REBOOT OF UKRAINIAN NUCLEAR POWER PLANT — </strong>Russia is building power lines in occupied southeastern Ukraine to connect Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, which Russia has captured, to its own grid, according to a new Greenpeace report cited by the <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=5e6b2ad55b&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;"><em>New York Times</em></a><em>.  </em><br>
<br>
The <em>Times</em> cites the construction as evidence that Moscow means to use the power plant to generate electricity for territory it now controls.<br>
<br>
Satellite images published by Greenpeace show that since early February, Russia has built more than 50 miles of electricity lines and pylons between the occupied Ukrainian cities of Mariupol and Berdyansk, along the coast of the Azov Sea. Greenpeace said the new power lines appeared to link to a large substation near Mariupol that is connected to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant,   <br>
The <em>Times</em> reported that if Russia restarts Zaporizhzhia for its own purposes, that would conflict with the Trump administration’s recent efforts to include the fate of the plant as part of possible peace talks.<br>
<br>
A White House <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=ee72870ef2&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">peace</a><a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=3f879cf5b4&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;"> plan</a> presented last month proposed that Russia would return the plant to Ukraine and that it would be put under U.S. management, to supply electricity to both Ukraine and Russia. Russia has rejected the idea. Foreign Minister <strong>Sergey Lavrov</strong> told <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=534be34c86&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">CBS News</a> that the Zaporizhzhia plant was being run by the Russian nuclear power company Rosatom and that he did not think “any change is conceivable.”</p>

                        </td>

    <tbody class="mcnTextBlockOuter">
        <tr>
            <td valign="top" class="mcnTextBlockInner" style="padding-top: 9px;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;">
              	<!--[if mso]>
				<table align="left" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="width:100%;">
				<tr>

				<!--[if mso]>

				<![endif]-->
                <table align="left" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="max-width: 100%;min-width: 100%;border-collapse: collapse;mso-table-lspace: 0pt;mso-table-rspace: 0pt;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;float: left;" width="100%" class="mcnTextContentContainer">
                    <tbody><tr>

                        <td valign="top" class="mcnTextContent" style="padding-top: 0;padding-right: 18px;padding-bottom: 9px;padding-left: 18px;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;word-break: break-word;color: #202020;font-family: Arial, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size: 16px;line-height: 125%;text-align: left;">

                            <p dir="ltr" style="margin: 10px 0;padding: 0;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #202020;font-family: Arial, 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size: 16px;line-height: 125%;text-align: left;"><strong>EUROPE FACES QUESTIONS ABOUT ITS OWN DEFENSE — </strong>Amid shifts in U.S. security policy away from Europe – and in some cases towards Moscow – officials and experts are raising questions about whether Europe can defend itself. General <strong>Philip Breedlove</strong>, a <em>Cipher Brief</em> expert who served as the Supreme Allied Commander for Europe, recently completed a multi-country tour of the continent as it grapples with these questions about U.S. commitments. He spoke with <em>The Cipher Brief</em> about broad European military needs, and the specific requirements of so-called frontline European states in countering threats from Russia.<br>
 <br>
“Deterrence is in the mind of the deterred, and clearly most people like me think about deterrence,” General Breedlove said. “They think of capability and credibility. I think the West and NATO have plenty of capability to deter Mr. Putin. I do not think the West has the credibility to deter Mr. Putin right now, and that’s worrisome… I think Mr. Putin senses weakness and he knows what to do in the presence of weakness.”<br>
 <br>
Read more in <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=20201688b3&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;"><em>The Cipher Brief</em></a>. <br>
 <br>
<strong>ITALIAN MAFIA GROUPS JOINING FORCES — </strong>Italian traditional organized crime groups, including the Cosa Nostra, Camorra and <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=1000cee255&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">'Ndrangheta</a>, have begun <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=4392e57230&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">fighting less and collaborating more</a>, Italy’s national anti-mafia agency (DIA) said in its annual report<em>.</em> Increased cooperation between the mafia groups could bolster their power and heighten the transnational crime risk in Europe.<br>
 <br>
The report highlighted that the mafia groups are increasingly involved in trying to control public works projects. "Coexistence has fostered synergies that have progressively become structured," DIA director <strong>Michele Carbone</strong> told a press conference. He cited concerns about mafia tentacles invading public works linked to Italy's EU-backed post-COVID Recovery Fund, construction of a bridge connecting Sicily to the mainland, and preparations for the 2026 Winter Olympics.<br>
 <br>
The DIA also noted that the mafia groups are increasing their technological prowess to improve operations, using technologies like encrypted communications and drones — something also seen in Mexican cartels, which <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=5e1e0fa04a&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;"><em>The Cipher Brief</em></a> has reported on. <br>
 <br>
<strong>CHINA BOOSTING PROTECTION OF MILITARY-INDUSTRIAL ASSETS — </strong>China issued new rules to boost the <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=2f0bdd3689&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">protection of military-industrial facilities</a> from espionage and sabotage. The new rules label facilities engaged in research, production, testing and storage of important weapons and equipment for China’s military as “protected areas.” The designation aims to boost the safety and secrecy of the listed facilities by making any act of disruption attempted spying punishable by law. <br>
 <br>
China’s heightened defensive measures aren’t unexpected. The U.S. is also heightening its guard against potential spying or sabotage amid the escalating military and technology competition with Beijing. <br>
 <br>
<strong>U.S. CONSIDERING FUTURE OF AFRICA MILITARY COMMAND —</strong> The future of <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=5e9e4a8a39&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">AFRICOM</a>, the U.S. military command for Africa, is in flux. General <strong>Michael Langley</strong>, AFRICOM’s commander, told reporters before a conference of African defense chiefs in Kenya that the U.S. is taking a closer look at what the military command will look like going forward. His comments come after reports that the U.S. military is shifting its approach in Africa, urging local allies to <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=b82fea590a&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;">take greater responsibility for their own security</a> — a dynamic comparable to the U.S. approach in Europe. <br>
 <br>
General Langley told reporters that he has asked African counterparts and interlocutors to make clear their views about what the future of AFRICOM should be: "That's what I tell them. I said: 'Okay, if we're that important to (you), you need to communicate that and we'll see'.” <br>
 <br>
AFRICOM was founded in 2007 to better address rising national security concerns in Africa, from Islamist insurgencies to competition with Russia and China. <br>
 <br>
In recent years, U.S. and allied security influence in West Africa has waned; the Sahel states of Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso all forced the withdrawal of U.S. and allied Western troops following a series of military coups. Russia has been moving to fill the gap left by the Western pullout. Militant Islamist groups — some with ties to al Qaeda and Islamic State — have been on the rise in the region amid the resulting power vacuum. General Langley said that despite the reduced U.S. influence in the Sahel region, Washington maintains some intelligence sharing with the military juntas there and is looking for “other ways to continue to stay engaged.”<br>
 <br>
<strong>A LESSER-KNOWN BATTLE OF D-DAY — </strong>The D-Day invasion of Normandy – more than eight decades ago – played out in theaters beyond the famed beaches at Normandy. In the nearby French town of St. Mere Eglise, troopers of the 82nd Airborne Division captured and held the small La Fiere bridge to prevent German reserves from counterattack U.S. forces at the beach landing. The battle for the bridge is the subject of James Donovan’s latest book “<a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=e6101e2de0&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;"><em>Nothing But Courage</em></a><em>.”</em> Major General (Ret.) <strong>Jack Leide</strong>, a veteran of 37 years of service in the U.S. Army, who served as a combat airborne infantry and intelligence officer in the 82nd Airborne Division, reviews the book in <em>The Cipher Brief</em>.<br>
 <br>
“Donovan set out to tell the full story of one of the most operationally critical, although lesser-known, stories of World War II and one that would play a key part particularly in the eventual success of the D-day landings,” Major General Leide writes. “His book is filled, end to end, with incredibly researched depictions of valor by the paratroopers and glider-men of the 82nd Airborne Division.” <br>
 <br>
Read the full review in <a href="https://thecipherbrief.us10.list-manage.com/track/click?u=9775ab595d580738d839f9d01&id=8f20be7370&e=55bbe501e9" style="mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;color: #d61043;font-weight: bold;text-decoration: underline;"><em>The Cipher Brief</em></a>. <br>

44.subject: Editors’ Picks: How America blew its unipolar moment
44.body:
Plus: Turkish guns are taking over the U.S. market.
MAY 27, 2025  |  VIEW IN BROWSER  |  SUBSCRIBE
 
 

A man dressed in a U.S. military uniform carries an American flag along a beach in Normandy, France, on June 6, 2017. Chesnot/Getty Images

1

How America Blew Its Unipolar Moment 

An international order founded not on institutions but on hegemonic benevolence proved impossible to sustain.

By Max Bergmann

 
2

Turkish Guns Are Taking Over the U.S. Market

They’re cheap, popular, and spreading beyond borders.

By Naomi Cohen

 
3

America Still Has a ‘Values-Based’ Foreign Policy

It’s increasingly difficult to understand Trump’s foreign policy without an ideological lens.

By Oren Samet

 
4

The U.S. Military Needs to Relearn Nuclear Signaling

A more flexible force can be a stronger deterrent in a crisis.

By Philip Sheers

 
5

When the Supreme Court Stood Firm on Habeas Corpus

Stephen Miller’s recent remarks about suspending the writ echo attempts at presidential overreach after 9/11.

By Julian E. Zelizer

Sponsored by McKinsey Health Institute

The path toward a metabolic health revolution

Surging global interest in obesity stemming from new weight management drugs presents a major opportunity for society: stay the course and prioritize obesity treatment, or work toward a broader vision of achieving metabolic health for all. A new McKinsey Health Institute report explores how this could boost annual GDP by $5.65 trillion from 2050 and reclaim 469 million years of healthier life.
 

Tariffs, Trade & Trump

Introducing “The Trade Wars,” the inaugural edition of FP Collections. Essential articles on tariffs unpack today's turbulent trade landscape. To download the collection, subscribe today.

EXPLORE NOW
 

You’re receiving this email at garrido.juanjo@gmail.com because you signed up for FP's Editors' Picks newsletter.

MANAGE YOUR EMAIL PREFERENCES  |  VIEW OUR PRIVACY POLICY  |  UNSUBSCRIBE 

 Interested in partnering with FP on events, podcasts, or research? Explore FP Solutions.

45.subject: Twins’ mysterious deaths, middle age weight loss, summer TV preview
45.body:
Subject Line: Twins’ mysterious deaths, middle age weight loss, summer TV preview Preheader: It’s been a busy day. Here’s what you might have missed. It looks like your email client might not support HTML formatted email. Try opening this email in another email client. Or, open the following link to view this email in a browser: https://e.newsletters.cnn.com/click? ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We respect your privacy, if this e-mail has been sent to you by error or you no longer wish to receive email, open the following link in a browser to unsubscribe: https://e.newsletters.cnn.com/click?
It’s been a busy day. Here’s what you might have missed.

Tuesday, May 27, 2025

View in browser
 

By Daniel Wine

Losing weight in middle age could set you up for a longer and healthier life, a new study found. The benefits include a lower risk of chronic diseases and death.

 

Here’s what else you might have missed during your busy day.

Lynsey Weatherspoon/Redux for CNN

1

 

Mystery solved

Twin 19-year-old brothers Qaadir and Naazir Lewis were found shot to death at the remote summit of a mountain in northern Georgia. Their deaths baffled the close-knit family for months, but police now say they know what happened.

2

 

‘A major issue’

A sperm donor with a rare genetic mutation fathered 67 children, and now 10 of them have been diagnosed with cancer. Advocates say there’s a need for greater regulation and a limit on the number of births allowed from a single donor.

3

 

You snooze, you lose?

When jolted awake by a blaring alarm clock, it’s tempting to reach for the snooze button. “Just five more minutes” is practically a morning mantra. But you could be silently sabotaging your shut-eye. Experts explain the pros and cons.

4

 

What to watch

With the dog days of summer approaching, our entertainment team rounded up the best new series and movies coming to a TV screen near you, including a drama from the creator of “Succession” and an Adam Sandler comedy sequel.

 

Sponsor Content by FinanceBuzz

Tackle your credit card debt by paying 0% interest until 2027

Got credit card debt? A 0% intro APR credit card could help you pay it down without extra interest. Our experts found the best cards to tackle debt without adding more. Click to see the top picks and why everyone’s talking about them!

 

5

 

Gone viral

Archie and Miles Shephard used to work together as salesmen in a lumber yard. Now they’re social media stars known for their high-energy and hilarious interpretations of some of the most dramatic moments in sports.

watch this

 
 

💥 Big boom: A home security camera captured the moment a box truck exploded while passing through a residential neighborhood in Addison, Illinois. The driver walked away with only minor injuries.

 

Sponsor Content by FinanceBuzz

Hands down one of the best credit cards of 2025

Getting a low interest card can help ease pressure while you pay down your balances. Experts identified this card for anyone looking to pay down debt and earn up to 20,000 miles after spending $500 in the first three months!

 

top headlines

 
  • RFK Jr. says Covid-19 shot will no longer be recommended for healthy children and pregnant women
  • Trump considers new sanctions on Russia as he grows more furious with Putin
  • NPR sues Trump over executive order to cut funding

70

🇩🇰 That’s about to be the new retirement age in Denmark, and it’s the highest in Europe.

check this out

 

Joe Giddens/PA/AP

🧀 Hole-y rollers: It’s been described as the world’s most dangerous race, and it’s certainly one of the most ridiculous — people tumbling down a steep hill in pursuit of a wheel of Double Gloucester cheese. Contestants explain why it’s so thrilling.

quotable

 

“This chapter is over. The story? Still being written. Thanks to all.”

—Cristiano Ronaldo

⚽ What’s next? The Portuguese soccer star threw his future into doubt with a cryptic message on social media after scoring his 25th goal on the final day of the Saudi Pro League season.

quiz time

 

Kayla Bartkowski/Getty Images

📖 Whose voice narrates the audiobook version of first lady Melania Trump’s memoir?

A. Megyn Kelly

B. Barron Trump

C. Morgan Freeman

D. Her own voice using AI

⬇️ Scroll down for the answer.

pick of the day

 

Brought to you by CNN Underscored

Limp, lifeless hair? Give it a lift with the best volumizing shampoos

If you envy celebs who have voluminous, light-as-air hair, volumizing shampoo may be the missing piece of your hair care routine. CNN Underscored’s beauty editor consulted hair experts who served up their go-to shampoos. From $9 drugstore picks to luxury department store picks, shop the 17 shampoos that will help give you volume.

good vibes

 

🐼 Cute overload: Hong Kong’s first locally born baby pandas — affectionately known as “Elder Sister” and “Little Brother” — finally have actual names after a contest that drew more than 35,000 entries. Take a look.

thanks for reading

 

👋 We’ll see you tomorrow.

🧠 Quiz answer: D. The first lady said her memoir is narrated “entirely using artificial intelligence in my own voice.”

52.subject: Four reasons to be optimistic about AI’s energy usage
52.body:
What's Next in Tech By MIT Technology Review By MIT Technology Review Read this article on LinkedIn to join the conversation Read on LinkedIn https://www.linkedin.com/comm/pulse/four-reasons-optimistic-ais-energy-usage-mit-technology-review-e53ne?lipi=urn%3Ali%3Apage%3Aemail_email_series_follow_newsletter_01%3BzjQcLHibSsCLtX28%2B9nrKw%3D%3D&midToken=AQFFcFlKxL3fwg&midSig=2XH_yDamLLErM1&trk=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-null-0-read_more_banner_cta_&trkEmail=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-null-0-read_more_banner_cta_-null-3qjwz5~mb6s7039~13-null-null&eid=3qjwz5-mb6s7039-13&otpToken=MTAwNzFiZTkxYjI5Y2VjMGIxMjQwNGVkNDIxNmU0YjI4OWNkZDk0ODliYTc4ZDYxNzdjMjA0NjY0YjVhNTVmM2YyZGZkNGE3MTdmM2JhZTI0Y2JmYzM1ZmNiN2I3NWIwNDA4ZmZjMDQxYzM2MDQxNWRlYTAsMSwx Despite the talk of rocketing costs and the climate impact of AI, you can still find reasons to be hopeful about where the industry is headed. There are innovations underway that could improve the efficiency of the software behind AI models, the computer chips those models run on, and the data centers where those chips hum around the clock. In this edition of What’s Next in Tech, find out why there are still reasons to be optimistic about AI’s energy use. ⚡ What's Next in Tech Readers: Claim your special, FREE 30-day trial subscription today. While there are reasons to be concerned about AI’s climate impact, all hope is not lost. Here’s why. More efficient models: The most obvious place to start is with the models themselves—the way they’re created and the way they’re run. AI models are built by training neural networks on lots and lots of data. Large language models are trained on vast amounts of text, self-driving models are trained on vast amounts of driving data, and so on. But the way such data is collected is often indiscriminate. Large language models are trained on data sets that include text scraped from most of the internet and huge libraries of scanned books. The practice has been to grab everything that’s not nailed down, throw it into the mix, and see what comes out. This approach has certainly worked, but training a model on a massive data set over and over so it can extract relevant patterns by itself is a waste of time and energy. There might be a more efficient way. Children aren’t expected to learn just by reading everything that’s ever been written; they are given a focused curriculum. Raquel Urtasun, founder and CEO of the Canadian robotruck startup Waabi, thinks we should do something similar with AI, training models with more curated data tailored to specific tasks. More efficient computer chips: As the software becomes more streamlined, the hardware it runs on will become more efficient too. There’s a tension at play here: In the short term, chipmakers like Nvidia are racing to develop increasingly powerful chips to meet demand from companies wanting to run increasingly powerful models. But in the long term, this race isn’t sustainable. Companies like Microsoft and OpenAI are losing money running their models inside data centers to meet the demand from millions of people. Smaller models will help. Another option is to move the computing out of the data centers and into people’s own machines. But getting AI models (even small ones) to run reliably on people’s personal devices will require a step change in the chips that typically power those devices. These chips need to be made even more energy efficient because they need to be able to work with just a battery. Experimental new chip designs are on the horizon. More efficient cooling in data centers: Another huge source of energy demand is the need to manage the waste heat produced by the high-end hardware on which AI models run. With the shift to processors like GPUs, and with even newer chip designs on the horizon, it is hard to predict what kind of hardware a new data center will need to house—and thus what energy demands it will have to support—in a few years’ time. But in the short term the safe bet is that chips will continue getting faster and hotter. With so many high-powered chips squashed together, air cooling (big fans, in other words) is no longer sufficient. Water has become the go-to coolant because it is better than air at whisking heat away. That’s not great news for local water sources around data centers. But there are ways to make water cooling more efficient. Cutting costs goes hand in hand with cutting energy use: Sustainability is often an afterthought or a nice-to-have. But with AI, the best way to reduce overall costs is to cut your energy bill. That’s good news, as it should incentivize companies to increase efficiency. Companies will be forced to think hard about how and when they use AI, choosing smaller, bespoke options whenever they can. AI is fast becoming a commodity, which means that market competition will drive prices down. To stay in the game, companies will be looking to cut energy use for the sake of their bottom line if nothing else. Read the full story to learn more about the innovations behind these four silver linings. This story is a part of MIT Technology Review’s brand-new series “Power Hungry: AI and our energy future,” on the energy demands and carbon costs of the artificial-intelligence revolution. Explore the full package. Get ahead with these related stories: AI’s energy impact is still small—but how we handle it is huge — The rising energy cost of data centers is a vital test case for how we deal with the broader electrification of the economy. We did the math on AI’s energy footprint. Here’s the story you haven’t heard. — The emissions from individual AI text, image, and video queries seem small—until you add up what the industry isn’t tracking and consider where it’s heading next. Everything you need to know about estimating AI’s energy and emissions burden — Here’s how MIT Technology Review waded through a mess of data and hidden variables to calculate the individual and collective energy demand from AI. Everyone is talking about AI. Be a part of the conversation with our weekly AI newsletter, The Algorithm. Sign up for free today. Image: Shiwen Sven Wang Keep reading on LinkedIn https://www.linkedin.com/comm/pulse/four-reasons-optimistic-ais-energy-usage-mit-technology-review-e53ne?lipi=urn%3Ali%3Apage%3Aemail_email_series_follow_newsletter_01%3BzjQcLHibSsCLtX28%2B9nrKw%3D%3D&midToken=AQFFcFlKxL3fwg&midSig=2XH_yDamLLErM1&trk=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-newsletter_content_preview_text-0-readmore_button_&trkEmail=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-newsletter_content_preview_text-0-readmore_button_-null-3qjwz5~mb6s7039~13-null-null&eid=3qjwz5-mb6s7039-13&otpToken=MTAwNzFiZTkxYjI5Y2VjMGIxMjQwNGVkNDIxNmU0YjI4OWNkZDk0ODliYTc4ZDYxNzdjMjA0NjY0YjVhNTVmM2YyZGZkNGE3MTdmM2JhZTI0Y2JmYzM1ZmNiN2I3NWIwNDA4ZmZjMDQxYzM2MDQxNWRlYTAsMSwx ---------------------------------------- This email was intended for Juanjo Garrido Serrato (Senior Space and Quantum Systems Architect) Learn why we included this: https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/4788?lang=en&lipi=urn%3Ali%3Apage%3Aemail_email_series_follow_newsletter_01%3BzjQcLHibSsCLtX28%2B9nrKw%3D%3D&midToken=AQFFcFlKxL3fwg&midSig=2XH_yDamLLErM1&trk=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-SecurityHelp-0-textfooterglimmer&trkEmail=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-SecurityHelp-0-textfooterglimmer-null-3qjwz5~mb6s7039~13-null-null&eid=3qjwz5-mb6s7039-13&otpToken=MTAwNzFiZTkxYjI5Y2VjMGIxMjQwNGVkNDIxNmU0YjI4OWNkZDk0ODliYTc4ZDYxNzdjMjA0NjY0YjVhNTVmM2YyZGZkNGE3MTdmM2JhZTI0Y2JmYzM1ZmNiN2I3NWIwNDA4ZmZjMDQxYzM2MDQxNWRlYTAsMSwx You are receiving LinkedIn notification emails. It looks like your email client might not support HTML formatted email. Try opening this email in another email client. Or, open the following link to view this email in a browser: https://e.newsletters.cnn.com/click? ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We respect your privacy, if this e-mail has been sent to you by error or you no longer wish to receive email, open the following link in a browser to unsubscribe: https://e.newsletters.cnn.com/click?
Russia-Ukraine... Israel ... Liverpool crash ... National Security Council ... Mass shootings ...

Tuesday, May 27, 2025

View in browser
 

By Jade Walker

The manhunt continues for the last two of 10 inmates who escaped from a New Orleans jail earlier this month. Authorities are also searching for a former police chief serving time for rape and murder who fled from an Arkansas prison on Sunday. What prompted these prison breaks? CNN's Zoe Sottile discovered several factors, including staffing shortages, aging facilities and “nothing to lose.”

 

Here's what else you need to know to get up to speed and on with your day.

A drone explosion lights up the sky over Kyiv during a Russian strike on Ukraine over the weekend. Gleb Garanich/Reuters

1

 

Russia-Ukraine

Russia launched overnight attacks on Ukraine on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, killing at least 29 people — including children— and wounding dozens more. The Kremlin’s intensified aerial bombardment came as international pressure mounted on Russian President Vladimir Putin to accept a ceasefire proposal. Even President Donald Trump took issue with Putin’s recent actions. “I’ve always had a very good relationship with Vladimir Putin of Russia, but something has happened to him. He has gone absolutely CRAZY!” Trump posted on Truth Social. On Monday, the Kremlin downplayed Trump’s remarks, categorizing them as “emotional reactions.” Also on Monday, Germany and other Ukrainian allies lifted restrictions on Kyiv firing long-range missiles into Russia following the massive aerial attacks, a move the Kremlin slammed as a "dangerous" decision.

2

 

Israel

A rally over the weekend in Tel Aviv’s Hostage Square demanding the return of captives from Hamas included a special speaker: an Israel Defense Forces soldier who was freed during a ceasefire hostage deal in January. On Sunday, Na’ama Levy said one of her biggest fears in captivity involved the Israeli airstrikes. “They (strikes) come unexpectedly. At first you hear the whistles, you pray that it won’t fall on us, and then — the explosions, a noise so loud that it paralyzes the body, and the ground shakes,” Levy told a crowd of thousands. “Every time, I was sure that this was the end of me. It was one of the scariest things I experienced there and that’s also what endangered me more than anything.” Earlier this month, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that defeating Israel’s enemies was the “supreme objective,” more important than securing the release of the remaining hostages in Gaza. His comments drew backlash from representatives of hostage families. 

3

 

Liverpool crash

A 53-year-old British man was arrested on Monday after he allegedly drove into a crowd of fans attending the Liverpool Football Club's Premier League victory parade. Dozens of people, including four children, were injured in the incident. The event was just winding down when a gray minivan plowed into the soccer team’s supporters, video from social media appeared to show. The angry crowd then surrounded and attacked the vehicle. Four people — three adults and one child — had to be removed from underneath the vehicle, according to officials. Police said they were not looking for any other suspects and were not treating the incident as terrorism. The crash “has cast a very dark shadow over what had been a joyous day,” Liverpool city council leader Liam Robinson said in a post on X. 

4

 

National Security Council

The Trump administration has placed more than 100 officials at the National Security Council on administrative leave. The NSC is staffed by experts from across the government who help to coordinate the president’s foreign policy agenda. Late Friday, the affected staffers received an email titled “Your return to home agency.” The email stated they were dismissed and had 30 minutes to clean out their desks. Those put on leave included career officials as well as political hires made during the Trump administration. The move was reportedly part of a restructuring under interim national security adviser and Secretary of State Marco Rubio. 

 
 

Sponsor Content by FinanceBuzz

Tackle your credit card debt by paying 0% interest until 2027

Got credit card debt? A 0% intro APR credit card could help you pay it down without extra interest. Our experts found the best cards to tackle debt without adding more. Click to see the top picks and why everyone’s talking about them!

 

5

 

Mass shootings

The terrible toll from mass shootings in America continues to climb. At least 10 people were shot in Little River, South Carolina, on Sunday after a holiday weekend gathering turned violent. Police released few details about the incident, including what prompted the gunfire, but did say that some of the injured were in critical condition. Detectives are still trying to determine who was responsible. Then on Monday night, two people were killed and nine others injured in a mass shooting in Philadelphia’s Fairmount Park, authorities said. The names of the victims have not been released, but Philadelphia Police Commissioner Kevin Bethel said an adult man and an adult woman had died. According to the Gun Violence Archive, as of May 27, there have been 122 mass shootings in the US this year.

 

breakfast browse

 

People are talking about these. Read up. Join in.

Team USA takes gold in Sweden
For the first time since 1933, the US men’s hockey team triumphed at the IIHF World Championship tournament. During the trophy presentation, Team USA held up the jersey of Johnny Gaudreau, the former USA and NHL player who died last year, along with his brother, after they were fatally struck by a suspected drunken driver.

 

Billie Eilish triumphs at AMAs
Although she didn't attend the American Music Awards ceremony in Las Vegas, Eilish won all seven awards she was nominated for, including artist of the year, album of the year and song of the year.

And the Palme d’Or goes to …
Iranian director, screenwriter and producer Jafar Panahi, who had previously been imprisoned by the Iranian government, received the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival for his new movie.

'Trayvon Martin of the 1930s in Atlanta’ honored
Imam Plemon El-Amin recently took the stage at Morehouse College to accept his late uncle’s honorary bachelor’s degree in religion. El-Amin’s uncle, Dennis Hubert, was an 18-year-old Black divinity student in 1930 when a mob of seven White men lynched him on the playground of an Atlanta school.

 

Lorde of the dance
Fans attending a Lorde-themed club night in Sydney, Australia, were shocked and thrilled when the Grammy-winning singer showed up.

 
 
 

Sponsor Content by FinanceBuzz

Hands down one of the best credit cards of 2025

Getting a low interest card can help ease pressure while you pay down your balances. Experts identified this card for anyone looking to pay down debt and earn up to 20,000 miles after spending $500 in the first three months!

 

in memoriam

 

Trailblazing New York congressman Charles Rangel dies at 94
A civil rights activist and war hero, Rangel became one of the most influential Black politicians in modern history. The Democrat was elected to Congress in 1970 and would eventually serve 23 terms. He also co-founded the Congressional Black Caucus and became the first Black member and later chairman of the influential House Ways and Means Committee.

 

114 billion

That’s how many pennies are currently in circulation in the US. Although the Treasury Department recently announced plans to stop production of the one-cent coin, the penny will remain legal tender.

 

quotable

 

“As you navigate the world of bright possibilities that awaits you, I urge you to take on the challenge and the opportunity to serve your fellow citizens. Fifty years from now, you will want to be able to look in the mirror and know that you did what you thought was right, in every part of your life. At the end of the day, your integrity is all you have. Guard it carefully.”

 

— Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, in a speech at a pre-graduation ceremony at Princeton University amid months of unrelenting personal attacks from President Trump.

 

pick of the day

 

Brought to you by CNN Underscored

Our 29 favorite Father’s Day gifts we’ve ever given and received

If you’re looking for that perfect gift for Dad, the CNN Underscored editors have rounded up 29 of our favorite Father’s Day gifts we’ve given and received. From a waterproof speaker to an all-in-one trimmer, shop all our best gifts right here.

and finally...

 
 

Teens save family from fire 
Two New York teens were on their way home from the junior prom when they spotted a large garage fire. They immediately began banging on the front door to warn the family inside.

57.subject: Early Brief: The political climate
57.body:
Early Brief from The Washington Post

In today’s edition … What the Senate could change in the...

PUBLISHED BY   <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/3f88b0d/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/4/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>   READ ONLINE <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/camp-rw/?trackId=596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d&s=68358af795e93627b9f41950&utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&linknum=5&linktot=54>

Early Brief <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/3f88b0d/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/6/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>

 

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=1069949&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=default>

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=1069949&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=default>
