Since you haven't read in a while, we'll pause sending it to you. Let us know if you still would like to keep receiving it.

Yes, keep this newsletter <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/40bd174/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/9/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>

 

Dan Merica and Matthew Choi">       By Dan Merica <mailto:dan.merica@washpost.com> and Matthew Choi <mailto:matthew.choi@washpost.com>

<https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c208b/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/12/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>
Listen to this briefing <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c208b/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/13/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>

Good morning, Early Birds. We hope everyone enjoyed the long weekend. Thank you for sharing your Memorial Day plans! Send tips to earlytips@washpost.com <mailto:earlytips@washpost.com>. Thanks for waking up with us.

In today’s edition … What the Senate could change in the Republican mega-bill … Trump mixes it up on tariffs yet again … but first …
The political climate

Rep. Andrew R. Garbarino (R-New York), center, listens as fellow lawmakers cast their votes for speaker of the House on Oct. 20, 2023. (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

When President Joe Biden worked to get the Inflation Reduction Act passed — the biggest investment in combating climate change in history — he and his fellow Democrats branded it as the last hope for the country to stave off the most devastating effects of climate change. Biden set a target to reduce the nation’s emissions from its 2005 levels by 50 to 52 percent by 2030. The bill relied on tax credits to encourage a transition to clean energy, giving breaks to energy providers and small households alike to install cleaner energy sources, such as a solar, wind or nuclear power.

But House Republicans voted last week to do away with all of that.

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=default>

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=default>

Republicans’ mega-bill <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c208c/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/17/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>, officially called the One Big Beautiful Bill, would eliminate the clean energy tax credits for projects that start generating electricity after 2028 or whose construction starts 60 days after the bill goes into effect. There’s a bit more wiggle room for nuclear after lobbying by the nuclear lobby.

Democrats and climate activists are furious. The Inflation Reduction Act was the product of precarious negotiations, and Democrats spoke with existential dread about what would happen if they failed: rising sea levels, more climate disasters, ceding dominance in new energy technology to countries such as China. They now assert the Republicans’ changes will kill thousands of clean energy jobs, stall economic growth linked to new clean energy projects and throw the country off track to meet its climate goals.

“Clean energy investments are revitalizing American manufacturing, bringing good-paying jobs to our communities, and driving innovation,” said Gina McCarthy, who served as White House climate adviser under Biden and as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency under President Barack Obama.

“We’re in a so-called ‘energy emergency,’ ” she said in a statement, “why would we do anything to make it harder for consumers to decrease their energy usage and for businesses to manufacture more energy efficient products?”

The Biden administration’s 2030 goal was always ambitious and met with a lot of skepticism from the international community. President Donald Trump abandoned the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement during his first term. What would prevent a future Republican administration from doing the same? The Inflation Reduction Act was Democrats’ answer: We are baking these targets into law.

One study published by REPEAT Project at Princeton University found that repealing the tax credits and other climate investments under the Biden bill would increase greenhouse gases by 0.5 billion metric tons per year in 2030 and more than 1 billion metric tons by 2035.

To be clear, the Inflation Reduction Act fell short of the emissions reductions most Democrats were hoping for. Sen. Joe Manchin III, the West Virginia moderate whose support Democrats needed to pass their bill, insisted on the bill not favoring clean energy over fossil fuels, meaning some of the more punitive measures to tax fossil fuels were cut. But climate activists and Democrats still saw the bill as a good first step.

Advertisement

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=689175&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950>

 

Republicans have long argued that the tax credits are unfair to oil and natural gas, which need a lot of investment before they can be profitable. One of Republicans’ top priorities this year, especially among hard-line conservatives, is cutting government spending. If that means sacrificing the clean energy projects that they have derided as a “green new scam,” so be it.

But several other Republicans have seen the benefits of the tax credits in their backyards. The Inflation Reduction Act spurred clean energy projects across the country — a majority of which are in red districts <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c208d/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/19/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>. About $522 billion for local projects could be wiped away, Evan Halper and Maxine Joselow reported last week <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42b2b61/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/20/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>. A study by Energy Innovation Policy and Technology, a pro-clean energy group, found that electricity bills could also increase 50 percent by 2035 with the loss of new power production.

“The energy demand in the country by 2030 is going to grow by at least 25 percent. We can’t meet that demand if we’re pulling energy projects off the table,” Rep. Andrew R. Garbarino (R-New York) told us in the wee hours before the House voted on its bill Thursday.

Up until the last moments of House negotiations, Garbarino pressed House leadership to accommodate the clean energy projects in the final bill. He was up so late that he ended up sleeping through the final bill vote, though he said he would have supported it.

The Senate will take up the bill when it comes back to Washington next week, and the tax credits have some defenders among the upper chamber’s Republicans, too. (The energy portions are just one part of the House package that the Senate could end up changing, which Jacob Bogage and Theodoric Meyer have more on below).

“Our country is blessed with abundant natural resources and an entrepreneurial spirit that uniquely positions us to power both our economy and the world — enabling U.S. leadership in innovation, energy production, and manufacturing alike. Many of the investments that make this possible are enabled by current tax provisions, including some from the Inflation Reduction Act,” a group of Senate Republicans led by Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) wrote to Senate Majority Leader <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42b2b60/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/21/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> John Thune (R-South Dakota) last month.

But the Senate also has its fiscal hawks who would want to gut spending, probably helping preserve parts of the House bill. Senate Energy Committee Chairman Mike Lee (R-Utah) posted on X earlier this month: “Raise your hand if you’d like to get the government out of the business of energy subsidies.”

Advertisement

<https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=689179&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950>

 
The ‘big, beautiful bill’
Hi, it’s Jacob Bogage, back after a hectic week that saw the House push President Donald Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill over the finish line — for now. Pro tip: If you can avoid spending 25 consecutive hours at the U.S. Capitol to cover a tax bill, I highly recommend it. Now, let’s get down to business.

GOP senators say they are keen to leave their imprint on this giant tax package when it arrives in the upper chamber. Here’s an early rundown of all the things we expect to change:
SALT. The state and local tax deduction allows filers to write off their local tax payments from their federal tax balance. This had to be in the House legislation because a band of blue-state Republicans threatened to sink the package without it. But there are no blue-state Republicans in the Senate. And SALT is not popular among Senate tax writers. Raising the SALT cap is expensive and is seen as rewarding higher tax rates in left-leaning states. It could get stripped out of the bill in the Senate to try to bring down the cost of the legislation.   Clean energy credits. Some policies from the Inflation Reduction Act, mainly the ones surrounding lower-emission energy production, are popular in states such as Kentucky, North Carolina and Ohio, places involved in making electric vehicles and EV batteries. Some Senate Republicans have talked about wanting to preserve some of the clean energy programs, or at least wind them down slower than what the House wrote into its bill.   Millionaire tax. This was very unpopular in the House, and leading Senate tax-writers don’t like it either, but hear me out. Trump has privately endorsed higher tax rates on millionaires <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/4279b6f/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/23/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> to House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) and at least publicly said he would tolerate them <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c208e/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/24/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>. Raising taxes on those earners would generate a lot of revenue that would offset the $2.4 trillion cost of this bill (over 10 years). Some senators have told me they like the idea, and others have expressed an openness to it — if Trump will back them up. Keep your eye on this. I don’t think the idea is totally dead.   Debt limit. The House and Senate went into the reconciliation process divided on how to handle the debt ceiling, and they haven’t come to a resolution. The House voted to raise the borrowing cap by $4 trillion. The Senate wants $5 trillion. They could meet in the middle at $4.5 trillion, but that would be a little too obvious of a solution.   The Byrd rule. These are things the Senate may not want to change but must to comply with the “Byrd rule,” the complex regulations that govern the Senate reconciliation process. Generally, the Byrd rule allows reconciliation to touch spending, but not policy issues. The Senate parliamentarian determines what violates the Byrd rule, but she serves at the pleasure of Senate leadership. The GOP could get around the Byrd rule (and essentially eliminate the filibuster) by firing the parliamentarian or voting to ignore her ruling. The GOP last week already set new precedent to weaken the filibuster and the parliamentarian <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c208f/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/25/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>.
Our pal Theodoric Meyer has more here on how the Senate might change the bill <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2090/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/26/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>.

We’ll have more to say about this in the coming days and weeks (and months?). Help us cover this mammoth bill. Send secure news tips on Signal to jacobbogage.87 <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/40da762/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/27/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> . And follow me on Bluesky: @jacobbogage.bsky.social <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/40da764/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/28/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> .
Tariff watch
Trump plans to delay tariffs on the European Union until July 9 <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2091/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/29/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>, he said over the weekend. He had planned to put a 50 percent tariff on European <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2092/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/30/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> goods this coming Sunday.

This has become a bit of a familiar dance by now. Trump announces punishing tariffs, then backs off at the last minute with a delay. When the president first announced the 50 percent European tariffs last week, Wall Street remained relatively robust, expecting them to be a negotiating tactic.

Trump told reporters that he decided on the delay after speaking with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and agreed to further negotiations on a future trade agreement.

“She said she wants to get down to serious negotiation, because … they have to do that,” he said. “And we had a very nice call. And I agreed to move it.”
What we’re watching
After months of focus on the federal government caused his popularity to tank, and just days after the billionaire said he would pull back on his political giving <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42a9b2f/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/31/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>, Elon Musk needs a win in tonight’s SpaceX launches.

The rocket company, after two failures, will launch its Starship Flight 9 test mission around 7:30 p.m. Eastern time from its facility near Boca Chica Beach in South Texas. Our colleagues Kelsey Ables and Aaron Gregg covered the eighth <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2093/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/32/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> and seventh test missions <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2094/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/33/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>, both of which ended in failure. The launch in March grounded planes in Florida and sent debris streaking across the sky.

 

Get ready with The Post
Ukraine is increasingly worried about securing more U.S.-made Patriot air defense systems <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2095/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/34/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>, as stockpiles sent during the Biden administration are drying up and the new administration is resistant to sending more, six Ukrainian and Western officials tell Isobel Koshiw, Siobhán O’Grady and Ellen Francis.   Is it “oligarchs” or “rich people?” How about “people experiencing food insecurity,” rather than Americans going hungry? Or “justice-involved populations” instead of prisoners? As Democrats wrestle with who to be in the era of Trump, Naftali Bendavid reports, more party members — particularly centrists — are reviving the argument that Democrats need to rethink the words they use <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2096/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/35/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> to talk with the voters whose trust they need to regain.   Trump spoke at the U.S. Military Academy’s commencement <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2097/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/36/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> for the first time since 2020, a year when the school went through a racial reckoning and made efforts to be more inclusive. Trump has since eliminated a lot of those efforts to make the school more to his liking, Emily Davies, Cleve R. Wootson Jr. and Dan Lamothe report.   U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers are waiting at court hearings to swiftly deport <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2098/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/37/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> migrants shortly after their immigration cases are dismissed, Arelis R. Hernández and Maria Sacchetti report. It’s part of a push to expedite deportations that immigrant rights groups say curtail due process.   Charles B. Rangel, a gravelly voiced and exuberant congressman from the Harlem neighborhood of New York, who became the first African American chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee but was forced to relinquish that coveted position because of financial transgressions, died May 26 at a hospital in Manhattan <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c2099/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/38/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>. He was 94.

 

In your local paper

The Forum of Fargo-Moorhead (Fargo, North Dakota): A fascinating, dark story about crime and control <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c209a/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/39/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> from North Dakota, focused on the kingpin of the largest methamphetamine ring in the state, Michael Gamboa.

The Washington Post: Trump pardoned Culpeper County, Virginia, sheriff Scott Jenkins <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/car-ln-tr/42c209b/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/40/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> of bribery charges that landed him a 10-year prison sentence. He was convicted for accepting more than $75,000 in bribes in exchange for appointing wealthy businessmen as unpaid auxiliary deputies.

The Texas Tribune: A bill requiring public schools to display the Ten Commandments <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c209c/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/41/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> passed the Texas House.

 

Send a reply

With Memorial Day marking the unofficial start of summer, we’d love to know what our readers have planned. Are you going anywhere special this summer? Going anywhere new? Or keeping a summer tradition going? Let us know at earlytips@washpost.com <mailto:earlytips@washpost.com>.

Thanks for reading. You can follow Dan and Matthew on X: @merica <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/4235c6e/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/43/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950> and @matthewichoi <https://s2.washingtonpost.com/4235c6f/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/44/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950>.

href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/27/political-climate/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c208b%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F12%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950"><img style="display:block;width:37px;max-width:37px;" width="37" alt="" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/0a008d37153f5777d941cd676a240448-headphone_80px-80-80.png"></a></td> <td valign="middle" align="left" class="iconText"><p><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/27/political-climate/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c208b%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F13%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">Listen to this briefing</a></p></td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Good morning, Early Birds. We hope everyone enjoyed the long weekend. Thank you for sharing your Memorial Day plans! Send tips to <a href="mailto:earlytips@washpost.com" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">earlytips@washpost.com</a>. Thanks for waking up with us.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>In today’s edition</b> … What the Senate could change in the Republican mega-bill … Trump mixes it up on tariffs yet again … but first …</p> <h1>The political climate</h1> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="100%" align="center"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" style="line-height:0;" class="imgCell"> <img style="height:auto !important;max-width:640px !important;width:100%;" width="640" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/1812b7d10229010511201bc91bba67fd-KR5GPQCYHNVHJDGAU7LQKARKI4-1280-0.jpeg" alt="Rep. Andrew R. Garbarino (R-New York), center, listens as fellow lawmakers cast their votes for speaker of the House on Oct. 20, 2023. (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)"> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td> <p class="imageCap" style="color: #aaaaaa; font: 12px/120% 'fl', sans-serif; margin: 8px 0 16px;">Rep. Andrew R. Garbarino (R-New York), center, listens as fellow lawmakers cast their votes for speaker of the House on Oct. 20, 2023. (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">When President <b>Joe Biden </b>worked to get the Inflation Reduction Act passed — the biggest investment in combating climate change in history — he and his fellow Democrats branded it as the last hope for the country to stave off the most devastating effects of climate change. Biden set a target to reduce the nation’s emissions from its 2005 levels by 50 to 52 percent by 2030. The bill relied on tax credits to encourage a transition to clean energy, giving breaks to energy providers and small households alike to install cleaner energy sources, such as a solar, wind or nuclear power.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">But House Republicans voted last week to do away with all of that.</p> <table width="auto" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr> <td colspan="2" align="center" style="line-height:0;"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=906533&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=static" border="0" style="max-height:12px;"> </td> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" align="left" valign="top" style="padding:0 0 24px 0;line-height:0;font-size:0;" class="natAdTop"> <a href="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=default" target="_blank"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=default&li_coord=desktop&collapse_width=600" width="560" border="0" style="display:block;height:auto;width:100%;max-width:560px;" alt="" class="lihide"> </a> </td> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" align="left" valign="top" style="line-height:0;"> <!--[if !mso]><!--> <div style="display:none; float:left; overflow:hidden; width:0; max-height:0; line-height:0;" class="lishow"> <table width="auto" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="left" valign="top" style="padding:0 0 24px 0;"> <a href="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=default" target="_blank"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=906529&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950&stpe=default&li_coord=mobile&collapse_width=600" width="100%" border="0" style="display:block;height:auto;" alt="Advertisement"> </a> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </div><!--<![endif]--> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/05/22/trump-tax-bill-house-republicans/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c208c%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F17%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">Republicans’ mega-bill</a>, officially called the One Big Beautiful Bill, would eliminate the clean energy tax credits for projects that start generating electricity after 2028 or whose construction starts 60 days after the bill goes into effect. There’s a bit more wiggle room for nuclear after lobbying by the nuclear lobby.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Democrats and climate activists are furious. The Inflation Reduction Act was the product of precarious negotiations, and Democrats spoke<b> </b>with existential dread about what would happen if they failed: rising sea levels, more climate disasters, ceding dominance in new energy technology to countries such as China. They now assert the Republicans’ changes will kill thousands of clean energy jobs, stall economic growth linked to new clean energy projects and throw the country off track to meet its climate goals.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“Clean energy investments are revitalizing American manufacturing, bringing good-paying jobs to our communities, and driving innovation,” said <b>Gina McCarthy</b>, who served as White House climate adviser under Biden and as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency under President <b>Barack Obama</b>.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“We’re in a so-called ‘energy emergency,’ ” she said in a statement, “why would we do anything to make it harder for consumers to decrease their energy usage and for businesses to manufacture more energy efficient products?”</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">The Biden administration’s 2030 goal was always ambitious and met with a lot of skepticism from the international community. President <b>Donald Trump</b> abandoned the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement during his first term. What would prevent a future Republican administration from doing the same? The Inflation Reduction Act was Democrats’ answer: We are baking these targets into law.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">One study published by REPEAT Project at Princeton University found that repealing the tax credits and other climate investments under the Biden bill would increase greenhouse gases by 0.5 billion metric tons per year in 2030 and more than 1 billion metric tons by 2035.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">To be clear, the Inflation Reduction Act fell short of the emissions reductions most Democrats were hoping for. Sen. <b>Joe Manchin III</b>, the West Virginia moderate whose support Democrats needed to pass their bill, insisted on the bill not favoring clean energy over fossil fuels, meaning some of the more punitive measures to tax fossil fuels were cut. But climate activists and Democrats still saw the bill as a good first step.</p> <table width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr data-hide-when="sample"> <td class="ad-label mobile-border-top" align="center" bgcolor="#F0F0F0" colspan="2" style="background-color:#F0F0F0;border-top:1px solid #cccccc;color:#595959;font:300 16px 'fl', sans-serif;padding:24px 0 11px 0;">Advertisement</td> </tr> <tr data-hide-when="sample"> <td valign="top" align="center" bgcolor="#F0F0F0" style="padding:5px 0 40px;" class="adMainImg"> <table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr> <td colspan="2" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="line-height: normal;"> <a href="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=689175&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950" rel="nofollow"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=689175&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950" border="0" width="560" style="width: 100%; max-width: 560px !important;" alt="Advertisement"> </a> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td align="center" valign="top" height="24" style="font-size:24px;line-height:24px;border-top:1px solid #cccccc;"> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Republicans have long argued that the tax credits are unfair to oil and natural gas, which need a lot of investment before they can be profitable. One of Republicans’ top priorities this year, especially among hard-line conservatives, is cutting government spending. If that means sacrificing the clean energy projects that they have derided as a “green new scam,” so be it.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">But several other Republicans have seen the benefits of the tax credits in their backyards. The Inflation Reduction Act spurred clean energy projects across the country — <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/interactive/2024/climate-bill-biden-clean-energy/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c208d%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F19%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">a majority of which are in red districts</a>. About $522 billion for local projects could be wiped away, <b>Evan Halper</b> and <b>Maxine Joselow</b> <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/05/23/senate-clean-energy-tax-credits/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42b2b61%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F20%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">reported last week</a>. A study by Energy Innovation Policy and Technology, a pro-clean energy group, found that electricity bills could also increase 50 percent by 2035 with<b> </b>the loss of new power production.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“The energy demand in the country by 2030 is going to grow by at least 25 percent. We can’t meet that demand if we’re pulling energy projects off the table,” Rep. <b>Andrew R. Garbarino</b> (R-New York) told us in the wee hours before the House voted on its bill Thursday.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Up until the last moments of House negotiations, Garbarino pressed House leadership to accommodate the clean energy projects in the final bill. He was up so late that he ended up sleeping through the final bill vote, though he said he would have supported it.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">The Senate will take up the bill when it comes back to Washington next week, and the tax credits have some defenders among the upper chamber’s Republicans, too. (The energy portions are just one part of the House package that the Senate could end up changing, which <b>Jacob Bogage</b> and <b>Theodoric Meyer</b> have more on below).</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“Our country is blessed with abundant natural resources and an entrepreneurial spirit that uniquely positions us to power both our economy and the world — enabling U.S. leadership in innovation, energy production, and manufacturing alike. Many of the investments that make this possible are enabled by current tax provisions, including some from the Inflation Reduction Act,” a group of Senate Republicans led by Sen. <b>Lisa Murkowski </b>(R-Alaska) <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42b2b60/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/21/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">wrote to Senate Majority Leader</a> <b>John Thune</b> (R-South Dakota) last month.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">But the Senate also has its fiscal hawks who would want to gut spending, probably helping preserve parts of the House bill. Senate Energy Committee Chairman <b>Mike Lee</b> (R-Utah) posted on X earlier this month: “Raise your hand if you’d like to get the government out of the business of energy subsidies.”</p> <table width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr data-hide-when="sample"> <td class="ad-label mobile-border-top" align="center" bgcolor="#F0F0F0" colspan="2" style="background-color:#F0F0F0;border-top:1px solid #cccccc;color:#595959;font:300 16px 'fl', sans-serif;padding:24px 0 11px 0;">Advertisement</td> </tr> <tr data-hide-when="sample"> <td valign="top" align="center" bgcolor="#F0F0F0" style="padding:5px 0 40px;" class="adMainImg"> <table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" data-hide-when="sample"> <tbody> <tr> <td colspan="2" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="line-height: normal;"> <a href="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/click?s=689179&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950" rel="nofollow"> <img data-no-process="true" src="https://sli.washingtonpost.com/imp?s=689179&li=powerup&m=56b0da2a702ef8881a9b9491b9978456&p=68358af795e93627b9f41950" border="0" width="560" style="width: 100%; max-width: 560px !important;" alt="Advertisement"> </a> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td align="center" valign="top" height="24" style="font-size:24px;line-height:24px;border-top:1px solid #cccccc;"> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <h1>The ‘big, beautiful bill’</h1> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><i>Hi, it’s </i><i><b>Jacob Bogage</b></i><i>,</i><i><b> </b></i><i>back after a hectic week that saw the House push President </i><i><b>Donald Trump</b></i><i>’s One Big Beautiful Bill over the finish line — for now. Pro tip: If you can avoid spending 25 consecutive hours at the U.S. Capitol to cover a tax bill, I highly recommend it. Now, let’s get down to business.</i></p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">GOP senators say they are keen to leave their imprint on this giant tax package when it arrives in the upper chamber. Here’s an early rundown of all the things we expect to change:</p> <ul> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;"><b>SALT.</b> The state and local tax deduction allows filers to write off their local tax payments from their federal tax balance. This had to be in the House legislation because a band of blue-state Republicans threatened to sink the package without it. But there are no blue-state Republicans in the Senate. And SALT is not popular among Senate tax writers. Raising the SALT cap is expensive and is seen as rewarding higher tax rates in left-leaning states. It could get stripped out of the bill in the Senate to try to bring down the cost of the legislation.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;"><b>Clean energy credits.</b> Some policies from the Inflation Reduction Act, mainly the ones surrounding lower-emission energy production, are popular in states such as Kentucky, North Carolina and Ohio, places involved in making electric vehicles and EV batteries. Some Senate Republicans have talked about wanting to preserve some of the clean energy programs, or at least wind them down slower than what the House wrote into its bill.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;"><b>Millionaire tax. </b>This was very unpopular in the House, and leading Senate tax-writers don’t like it either, but hear me out. <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/05/08/trump-tax-millionaires-republicans/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F4279b6f%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F23%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">Trump has privately endorsed higher tax rates on millionaires</a> to House Speaker <b>Mike Johnson</b> (R-Louisiana) and at least <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c208e/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/24/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">publicly said he would tolerate them</a>. Raising taxes on those earners would generate a lot of revenue that would offset the $2.4 trillion cost of this bill (over 10 years). Some senators have told me they like the idea, and others have expressed an openness to it — if Trump will back them up. Keep your eye on this. I don’t think the idea is totally dead.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;"><b>Debt limit.</b> The House and Senate went into the reconciliation process divided on how to handle the debt ceiling, and they haven’t come to a resolution. The House voted to raise the borrowing cap by $4 trillion. The Senate wants $5 trillion. They could meet in the middle at $4.5 trillion, but that would be a little too obvious of a solution.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;"><b>The Byrd rule.</b> These are things the Senate may not want to change but must to comply with the “Byrd rule,” the complex regulations that govern the Senate reconciliation process. Generally, the Byrd rule allows reconciliation to touch spending, but not policy issues. The Senate parliamentarian determines what violates the Byrd rule, but she serves at the pleasure of Senate leadership. The GOP could get around the Byrd rule (and essentially eliminate the filibuster) by firing the parliamentarian or voting to ignore her ruling. The GOP last week already <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/05/22/california-senate-vehicle-emissions-rules-epa/56670bc0-3720-11f0-9c9e-0db2d748bea7_story.html?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c208f%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F25%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">set new precedent to weaken the filibuster and the parliamentarian</a>.</li> </ul> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Our pal <b>Theodoric Meyer</b> has <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/27/senate-reconciliation-big-bill/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2090%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F26%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">more here on how the Senate might change the bill</a>.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><i>We’ll have more to say about this in the coming days and weeks (and months?). Help us cover this mammoth bill. Send secure news tips on Signal to </i><a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/40da762/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/27/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;"><i>jacobbogage.87</i></a><i>. And follow me on Bluesky: </i><a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/40da764/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/28/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;"><i>@jacobbogage.bsky.social</i></a><i>.</i></p> <h1>Tariff watch</h1> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Trump plans to <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/25/trump-trade-tariffs-eu/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2091%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F29%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">delay tariffs on the European Union until July 9</a>, he said over the weekend. He had planned to put a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/05/23/trump-tariffs-eu-trade-war-iphone/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2092%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F30%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">50 percent tariff on European</a> goods this coming Sunday.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">This has become a bit of a familiar dance by now. Trump announces punishing tariffs, then backs off at the last minute with a delay. When the president first announced the 50 percent European tariffs last week, Wall Street remained relatively robust, expecting them to be a negotiating tactic.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">Trump told reporters that he decided on the delay after speaking with European Commission President<b> Ursula von der Leyen</b> and agreed to further negotiations on a future trade agreement.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">“She said she wants to get down to serious negotiation, because … they have to do that,” he said. “And we had a very nice call. And I agreed to move it.”</p> <h1>What we’re watching</h1> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">After months of focus on the federal government caused his popularity to tank, and just days after the billionaire said he would <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/20/elon-musk-less-political-spending/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42a9b2f%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F31%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">pull back on his political giving</a>,<b> Elon Musk</b> needs a win in tonight’s SpaceX launches.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">The rocket company, after two failures, will launch its Starship Flight 9 test mission around 7:30 p.m. Eastern time from its facility near Boca Chica Beach in South Texas. Our colleagues <b>Kelsey Ables </b>and <b>Aaron Gregg </b>covered <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/03/07/spacex-starship-explodes-debris-airports/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2093%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F32%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">the eighth</a> and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/01/17/spacex-starship-launch-lost-explosion-debris/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2094%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F33%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">seventh test missions</a>, both of which ended in failure. The launch in March grounded planes in Florida and sent debris streaking across the sky.</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="left" style="max-width:87.5%"> <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" align="center" style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" colspan="2" valign="top" height="30" style="border-bottom:1px solid #555555;font-size:30px;line-height:30px;"> </td> </tr> <tr> <td width="43" height="40" valign="top" align="left" style="padding:8px 0 20px 0;"> <img style="display:block;width:35px;max-width:35px;" width="35" alt="" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/a9192f43c32eb694029efbba4cf58a0e-nl-theearlybrief-campaignicon_tstmp_1714668928-101-101.png"> </td> <td align="left"> <h4 style="background-color:#ffffff;color:#000000;padding:6px 0 12px 0;">Get ready with The Post</h4> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <ul> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;">Ukraine is <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/05/26/ukraine-patriot-missiles-air-defense-raytheon/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2095%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F34%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">increasingly worried about securing more U.S.-made Patriot air defense systems</a>, as stockpiles sent during the Biden administration are drying up and the new administration is resistant to sending more, six Ukrainian and Western officials tell <b>Isobel Koshiw, Siobhán O’Grady </b>and<b> Ellen Francis</b>.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;">Is it “oligarchs” or “rich people?” How about “people experiencing food insecurity,” rather than Americans going hungry? Or “justice-involved populations” instead of prisoners? As Democrats wrestle with who to be in the era of Trump, <b>Naftali Bendavid</b> reports, more party members — particularly centrists — are <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/27/democrats-language-elite-politically-correct/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2096%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F35%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">reviving the argument that Democrats need to rethink the words they use</a> to talk with the voters whose trust they need to regain.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/05/24/trump-west-point-graduation-dei-military/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2097%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F36%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">Trump spoke at the U.S. Military Academy’s commencement</a> for the first time since 2020, a year when the school went through a racial reckoning and made efforts to be more inclusive. Trump has since eliminated a lot of those efforts to make the school more to his liking, <b>Emily Davies</b>, <b>Cleve R. Wootson Jr.</b> and <b>Dan Lamothe </b>report.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;">U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers are <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/05/23/immigration-court-arrests-ice-trump/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2098%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F37%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">waiting at court hearings to swiftly deport</a> migrants shortly after their immigration cases are dismissed, <b>Arelis R. Hernández</b> and <b>Maria Sacchetti </b>report. It’s part of a push to expedite deportations that immigrant rights groups say curtail due process.</li> <li style="color: #333333; font: 18px/185% 'Georgia', serif;"><b>Charles B. Rangel</b>, a gravelly voiced and exuberant congressman from the Harlem neighborhood of New York, who became the first African American chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee but was forced to relinquish that coveted position because of financial transgressions, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/obituaries/2025/05/26/charles-rangel-harlem-congress-dead/?utm_campaign=wp_power_up&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F42c2099%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950%2F596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d%2F38%2F54%2F68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">died May 26 at a hospital in Manhattan</a>. He was convicted for accepting more than $75,000 in bribes in exchange for appointing wealthy businessmen as unpaid auxiliary deputies.</p> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;"><b>The Texas Tribune:</b> A bill <a href="https://s2.washingtonpost.com/42c209c/68358af795e93627b9f41950/596d35ddae7e8a44e701cc5d/41/54/68358af795e93627b9f41950" target="_blank" style="color: #333333; text-decoration: underline;">requiring public schools to display the Ten Commandments</a> passed the Texas House.</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" role="presentation" width="87.5%" align="center" class="widthMB"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="left" style="max-width:87.5%"> <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" align="center" style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" colspan="2" valign="top" height="30" style="border-bottom:1px solid #555555;font-size:30px;line-height:30px;"> </td> </tr> <tr> <td width="43" height="40" valign="top" align="left" style="padding:8px 0 20px 0;"> <img style="display:block;width:35px;max-width:35px;" width="35" alt="" src="https://palomaimages.washingtonpost.com/pr2/a9192f43c32eb694029efbba4cf58a0e-nl-theearlybrief-campaignicon_tstmp_1714668928-101-101.png"> </td> <td align="left"> <h4 style="background-color:#ffffff;color:#000000;padding:6px 0 12px 0;">Send a reply</h4> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p style="margin:0 0 16px 0;">With Memorial Day marking the unofficial start of summer, we’d love to know what our readers have planned.
